'b''b''b''b''b'Preserving Landmarks for All New Yorkers'b''b'To the Editor:'b'As a professional preservationist, I take offense at the implicit charge of racial exclusion in a letter that states, \xe2\x80\x9cEmphasizing bricks and mortar can come at the expense of economic and ethnic diversity\xe2\x80\x9d (\xe2\x80\x9cBattle Lines in the Fight to Protect Sunnyside,\xe2\x80\x9d Jan. 7).'b'Landmark designation does not have a racial agenda. New York City\xe2\x80\x99s administrative code states clearly that \xe2\x80\x9cthe protection, enhancement, perpetuation and use\xe2\x80\x9d of buildings and \xe2\x80\x9clandscape features of special character or historical or aesthetic interest is a public necessity and is required in the interest of the health, prosperity, safety and welfare of the people.\xe2\x80\x9d The people, not \xe2\x80\x9csome\xe2\x80\x9d people.'b'Forty years of urban experience has shown that landmark designation works to forward this worthwhile municipal goal. Landmarking does not cause population exclusion or displacement, and to place it along with redlining, urban renewal and other racially charged planning practices is both incorrect and inappropriate.'b'Simeon Bankoff'b'Executive Director'b'Historic Districts Council'b'East Village'b''b''b''b'Fort Benning, Ga.'b'IN 1901, Gen. Leonard Wood, the American governor of occupied Cuba, wrote an incensed letter to President William McKinley after discovering deep corruption in the island\xe2\x80\x99s postal service. \xe2\x80\x9cWe have gone into Cuba to give these people an example of good government,\xe2\x80\x9d Wood insisted. \xe2\x80\x9cThese thefts in the post office are so far the only blot on our record. Our honor as a nation demands that we bring the thieves to trial.\xe2\x80\x9d He gave his commander in chief an ultimatum: \xe2\x80\x9cIf it is embarrassing to you to have me persist in this matter, I will resign.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'About the only difference between Cuba then and Iraq today is that Wood\xe2\x80\x99s intervention resulted in the jailing of the culprits. The level of corruption in the Iraq Security Forces is staggering. The Iraq Study Group found that $5 billion to $7 billion is lost annually to different types of corruption, and yet \xe2\x80\x9cthere are still no examples of senior officials who have been brought before a court and convicted of corruption charges.\xe2\x80\x9d The result: \xe2\x80\x9cEconomic development is hobbled by insecurity, corruption, lack of investment, dilapidated infrastructure and uncertainty.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Yet of the study group\xe2\x80\x99s 79 recommendations, only two are much relevant to this problem, and no anticorruption milestones to be achieved were set forth. Having served in Iraq, I find this very disappointing. While I can\xe2\x80\x99t of course speak officially for the Pentagon, I can describe what I saw and give my own thoughts on how to improve things.'b'The most prominent forms of corruption I saw were Iraqi commanders pocketing the paychecks of nonexistent troops in the Iraqi Army and officers in the police forces, and customs officials abetting the smuggling of oil and precious rebuilding supplies across Iraq\xe2\x80\x99s porous borders.'b'These are vast problems, but some relatively simple solutions could tamp them down considerably.'b'The greatest amount of corruption in the Iraq military and police forces occurs when payrolls are handed out at the unit level. Because the country doesn\xe2\x80\x99t have a functioning banking system that would allow easy money transfers to private accounts, military and security commanders receive large sums of cash every payroll period  based on the number and rank of soldiers on their personnel rosters. The endemic problem is that commanders frequently put nonexistent soldiers and security personnel \xe2\x80\x94 dubbed \xe2\x80\x9cghosts\xe2\x80\x9d by American overseers \xe2\x80\x94 on their rosters and pocket their salaries.'b'It is difficult to overstate how deeply these ghosts hurt the war effort. Most obviously, we have no idea how much of this money is being siphoned off to support tribal and ethnic fighting, and even the insurgency itself.'b'Also, because hundreds and thousands of ghosts exist at all echelons, many military and police units in the field do not have nearly as many men at arms as they seem to have on paper. Thus the units are often assigned tasks for which they do not have necessary manpower. And when American or other coalition forces are asked to \xe2\x80\x9cpartner\xe2\x80\x9d with Iraqi troops, we have often found that there simply aren\xe2\x80\x99t enough bodies to conduct training and missions.'b'American officials have long been aware of this problem. \xe2\x80\x9cThe number of trained and equipped security forces does not provide a complete picture of their capabilities and may overstate the number of forces on duty,\xe2\x80\x9d was the finding of the Government Accountability Office\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cStabilizing Iraq\xe2\x80\x9d report last fall. \xe2\x80\x9cFor example, Ministry of Interior data include police who are absent without leave.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Those of us on the ground discovered this the hard way. When I was with the Third Armored Cavalry Regiment in Nineveh Province in 2005, we tried for months to get the names of all Iraqi security personnel in our sector on the payrolls of the Ministries of Interior and Defense. We were curious because when we tried to assess the effectiveness of the Iraqi Border Police brigade in Sinjar, on the Syrian border, we were told by Iraqi commanders that at least 300 officers were \xe2\x80\x9cperforming guard duties in Mosul.\xe2\x80\x9d Mosul is more than 100 miles inside Iraq, so border troops had no business there, if indeed they existed at all.'b'Similarly, in South Baghdad, we American advisers assigned to the Fourth Brigade of the Sixth Iraqi Army Division had little luck getting a clear read of the brigade\xe2\x80\x99s strength. Iraqi commanders repeatedly told us that many of their men were \xe2\x80\x9celsewhere, performing security duties for the Ministry of Defense.\xe2\x80\x9d The advisers found personnel discrepancies as high as 30 percent in any given unit.'b'How can we bust the ghosts? Every soldier, police officer and government official is assigned a national identification number for bookkeeping, but so far it has been far too easy for corrupt officials to get numbers for nonexistent people. A better idea would be a universal national identification card for all government and military employees that includes the holder\xe2\x80\x99s photograph and fingerprints.'b'Such cards should be required for any Iraqi to receive his paycheck. Both the distribution of the cards and the payroll-distribution sites should be jointly overseen by coalition and Iraqi officials. There is no reason such a system could not be in place by the end of the year.'b'It would also help if American advisers embedded with security forces were charged with ensuring that all Iraqis are actually on duty with their assigned units. Should Iraqi commanders refuse to cooperate with their audits, we must insist that the Iraqi government fire them.'b'The second major source of corruption I witnessed is what I call the \xe2\x80\x9creverse Ho Chi Minh Trails\xe2\x80\x9d that facilitate smuggling of Iraqi oil and other resources out of the country. A United States interagency panel reported in November that oil smuggling abetted by corrupt Iraqi customs officials is netting the insurgents $100 million a year, helping to make them financially self-sustaining.'b'Because most of Iraq is landlocked, almost all goods going in and out pass through 14 land \xe2\x80\x9cports of entry.\xe2\x80\x9d Smuggling has always been a part of Iraqi life, and was even more so during the last years of Saddam Hussein\xe2\x80\x99s rule, because he encouraged it to counteract the embargo on Iraqi oil. Yet, almost immediately after the 2003 invasion, former customs officials from the regime resumed their duties at the ports of entry.'b'Later that year, we in the Third Armored Cavalry were given responsibility for the Syrian, Jordanian and Saudi Arabian borders along Anbar Province. In addition to helping create the new Iraqi Border Police force, we set about reforming the customs checkpoints.'b'At first, this was successful: for example, the border police battalion we trained at Walid, near the conjunction of the Syrian and Jordanian borders, uncovered many attempts to smuggle out large quantities of food, fuel, industrial parts and other goods. Hundreds of smugglers were arrested.'b'Unfortunately, we left Anbar in early 2004 and corrupt officials in Baghdad soon took away the border police\xe2\x80\x99s oversight authority on the grounds that it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t their \xe2\x80\x9cjurisdictional role to conduct operations that were assigned exclusively to customs officials.\xe2\x80\x9d American advisers at the national level failed to do anything about this, and things quickly reverted to the corrupt status quo.'b'The situation at Walid was hardly unique. In 2005 I returned to Iraq with the Third Armored Cavalry, this time to Nineveh Province, to cover the northern section of the border between Iraq and Syria. It soon became clear that the region\xe2\x80\x99s port of entry, at Rabiya, was a hotbed of corruption. Not only were customs officials apparently turning a blind eye to smuggling, but they seemed to be directly engaged in it.'b'And little has changed: last month the American special inspector general for Iraq, Stuart Bowen, reported that the pipelines in the area have been blown up, so the only way to export oil is by road. He noted, \xe2\x80\x9cThat leaves it vulnerable to smuggling as truckers sell their cargoes on the black market.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'How can we shut down this black market? First, we must insist that the Iraqi government replace the customs workers at the 14 land border crossings with a new set of at least 1,400 elite officials jointly selected and vetted by the Iraqi ministries and the coalition forces.'b'We should supplement this new force with teams of American advisers \xe2\x80\x94 soldiers, police officers, customs officials and the like \xe2\x80\x94 to ensure that the Iraqis are prepared to do their jobs. And we should create an anticorruption task force of coalition officers with the power to periodically review systemic issues like the Iraqis\xe2\x80\x99 recruitment methods, policies governing potential ethical problems and records of internal discipline.'b'The Iraq Study Group concluded that \xe2\x80\x9cthe ability of the United States to shape the outcomes is diminishing\xe2\x80\x9d and that \xe2\x80\x9ctime is running out.\xe2\x80\x9d Those of us who have been on the ground know how true this is. Irrespective of the number and mission of United States forces sent to Iraq, winning or losing will depend in large part on our ability to, in General Wood\xe2\x80\x99s phrasing, \xe2\x80\x9cgive these people an example of good government.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Tarrytown, N.Y.'b'THERE\xe2\x80\x99S invariably something risky, if not risible, about allowing Congress to decide what\xe2\x80\x99s for dinner. Bad decisions about agriculture have defined government policy for the last century; 70 percent of our nation\xe2\x80\x99s farms have been lost to bankruptcy or consolidation, creating an agricultural economy that looks more Wall Street than Main Street.'b'Now, after the uprooting of a thousand years of agrarian wisdom, we chefs have discovered something really terrible  \xe2\x80\x94 no, not that the agricultural system we help support hurts farmers and devastates farming communities, or that it harms the environment and  our health. What we\xe2\x80\x99ve discovered is that the food it produces just doesn\xe2\x80\x99t taste very good.'b'Who\xe2\x80\x99s responsible for the blandness? Look no further than Washington: There you will meet not farmers, but the people determining how our farmers farm. They do it through the farm bill, a mammoth piece of legislation that designates American agricultural policy every five years and that Congress is preparing to take up in its new session.'b'This is a  sweeping bill, omnibus in every sense \xe2\x80\x94 nutrition, conservation, genetic engineering, food safety, school lunch programs, water quality, organic farming and much more. It\xe2\x80\x99s really a food and farm bill. If you\xe2\x80\x99re a chef or a home cook or someone who just likes to eat, it affects you, because it determines what you eat and how what you eat is grown.'b'And the food that we grow on 200 million acres of harvested cropland is inedible. Stand in the middle of our farm belt and you\xe2\x80\x99ll see cornfields extending to the horizon, but the harvest won\xe2\x80\x99t be dinner, not until it\xe2\x80\x99s milled and processed into flours or starches, or used to fatten our animals on feedlots. Just four crops \xe2\x80\x94 corn, rice, soybeans and wheat \xe2\x80\x94 account for the vast majority  of our harvested acreage. Not surprising, given that these same crops account for 70 percent  of the total subsidies allotted to farmers.'b'No one wants farmers to suffer, especially chefs. But if we\xe2\x80\x99re spending $20 billion or so  a year on farm subsidies, we ought to invest in the foods we eat. And I mean'b' eat,'b' not process into something that resembles food. That means fewer subsidies for grains like corn and soy, and more help for growers of broccoli and tomatoes.'b'How do we do this? We could start by rewarding diversity over yield, basing subsidy payments not on how many acres of corn a farmer grows but on the number of varieties of crops he plants. We could also link payments to, say, the efficiency of nitrogen fixation (crop rotation helps the soil retain nitrogen, so farmers don\xe2\x80\x99t need to add it with chemicals) or equate them with how much a farm helps soil and water conservation. In effect, tie payments to plant health.'b'This doesn\xe2\x80\x99t mean the government needs to tell the farmer what to grow. Instead, show the farmer that there\xe2\x80\x99s more money to be made in a rich, diverse ecology and the planting strategy will change. Change the planting strategy, and whether it\xe2\x80\x99s grains or greens, the quality of what\xe2\x80\x99s harvested vastly improves.'b'Yes, the naughty thumb of science may have prodded the earth, as E. E. Cummings said, but there\xe2\x80\x99s nothing wrong with thumbing dollar bills in the direction of promoting a tastier food supply. That\xe2\x80\x99s the kind of green revolution that a chef can support.'b'But such thoughts are rarely on the minds of our legislators, or, so it seems, anyone else. Take as an example the insurance industry. Its policies favor big farms that grow a single commodity crop. If you\xe2\x80\x99re a farmer who wants to grow lots of different crops, it\xe2\x80\x99s almost impossible to get affordable coverage; to  insurers, you\xe2\x80\x99re pretty much the equivalent of a skydiving cigarette smoker.'b'The insurance regulations that are part of the farm bill need to address this disparity, because crop diversification should be exactly what insurers want: it helps to prevent the kind of natural disasters that insurance policies protect against, say, a devastating insect infestation. (Of course, it gives food lovers precisely what they want: more diversity, more variety, more flavor.) To this end, our agricultural policy should acknowledge the role of biodiverse farms in risk management by establishing discounts for farmers who practice this form of environmental stewardship and removing the discriminatory 5 percent premium surcharge on policies that encumbers organic producers under the current system.'b'While our legislators are at it, they might also look at another powerful paradox that chefs confront every day. If I want to purchase a case of carrots, it\xe2\x80\x99s much easier (and cheaper) to get them from the Salinas Valley, in California, than from the Hudson Valley that surrounds my restaurants. The food distribution system favors size. A distributor in California can send one truck to pick up 50 cases of carrots; a distributor procuring exclusively from  the Northeast will need to send 50 trucks to 50 different farms.'b'That\xe2\x80\x99s a shame, not just because a carrot that comes to New York from California gets singed with petroleum as it travels cross-country, but because at this time of year carrots pulled from the rich muck dirt of Western New York have 50 times more flavor than their West Coast counterparts.'b'Same with milk, which large industrial dairy farms sell with the iconic label of a smiling, muscle-flexed cow in front of open pasture and next to an old red barn. That\xe2\x80\x99s tantamount to false advertising, since the industrial dairy cow never sees a blade of fresh grass and has very few muscles to flex after receiving hormones to increase productivity. With 20,000 cows per farm, the animals spend a lot of time waiting in line for the next milking, so it\xe2\x80\x99s hard to imagine that there is a lot of smiling going on.'b'False representation aside, there\xe2\x80\x99s one point the powerful dairy industry won\xe2\x80\x99t let us forget: milk is pretty cheap. But  the real cost of milk is hidden in places like California, with its heavily subsidized irrigation system; if Western dairy farmers  had to pay the real cost of the irrigation-dependent alfalfa fed to cows, New England\xe2\x80\x99s milk prices would be more competitive. And if those cows ate a variety of grasses as they were meant to, instead of just alfalfa, \xe2\x80\x9cGot Milk?\xe2\x80\x9d would be more \xe2\x80\x9cGot Rich, Delicious and Affordable Milk?\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Though food transportation and irrigation subsidies exist outside the domain of the current farm bill, their implications cannot be overlooked as we review (and revise) our system of agriculture. The new bill needs to level the playing field by recognizing a region\xe2\x80\x99s agricultural strength \xe2\x80\x94 like New England\xe2\x80\x99s abundant supply of great grassland \xe2\x80\x94 and encouraging farmers through subsidies and other inducements to use it accordingly.'b'Then there\xe2\x80\x99s the question of meat and poultry. A breed of pig that tasted like pork (something other than the other white meat)? A chicken that actually saw pasture (and tasted  like ... chicken)? A steer with fat marbled on a grass diet, or a lamb that\xe2\x80\x99s been rotationally grazed? We\xe2\x80\x99re not asking for a lot, but no matter, it\xe2\x80\x99s not for sale, at least not by the big-food chain.'b'Unless you\xe2\x80\x99re a farmers\xe2\x80\x99 market devotee or savvy Internet user, or happen to live near a market that supports good animal husbandry, you depend on a system that raises animals in confinement. That\xe2\x80\x99s very large confinement \xe2\x80\x94 several thousand pigs to a barn, tens of thousands of chickens. The industrial model is efficiency through uniformity. A tastier model would be flavor through diversity \xe2\x80\x94 but the current farm bill won\xe2\x80\x99t allow it.'b'For one thing, federal rules prohibit the out-of-state sale of livestock and poultry products inspected by a state agency, which means if you want to raise more meat and expand  your farm by offering a niche product, you\xe2\x80\x99re stuck doing it only in your state  \xe2\x80\x94  if you can find a slaughterhouse. (Oh, federally inspected slaughterhouses are few and far between, and unless you\xe2\x80\x99re an agribusiness giant, nearly impossible get into.)'b'Local abbatoirs, besides feeling the pressure of land prices and unwelcoming neighbors, have to contend with unwieldy rules. A one-size-fits-all mentality dictates that mom-and-pop slaughterhouses must follow the same rules of inspection as industrial plants, even though these huge meat processors typically slaughter more cattle in a single hour (390 by Agriculture Department estimates) than their counterparts might see in a whole year.'b'Legislation to approve state-inspected meats was introduced in the last session by Representative Roy Blunt of Missouri. His bill calls for the Agriculture Department to certify all satisfactory state-inspection programs, thus enabling the 2,000 existing state-inspected meat processors to enter the national market, and paving the way for many more.'b'His bill would help, but so would a farm bill that put up fewer roadblocks to smaller-scale livestock farms and pulled the veil back on where our food comes from. We stamp \xe2\x80\x9cMade in the U.S.A.\xe2\x80\x9d on blue jeans and cars \xe2\x80\x94 but Americans can\xe2\x80\x99t find out where their food was grown. If Congress passes \xe2\x80\x94 and enforces \xe2\x80\x94 a rule in the 2007 bill requiring country of origin labeling, we\xe2\x80\x99d be more informed about the origins of our food supply and, to the great fear of our corporate brethren, we might ask a lot more questions. Questions like \xe2\x80\x9cWho\xe2\x80\x99s growing our food?\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cHow\xe2\x80\x99s it being grown?\xe2\x80\x9d are not easily answered anymore, especially when a package of frozen ground meat can  have  animal parts from as many as 20 countries.'b'Suggest to agribusiness interests that they think about flavor, though, and you\xe2\x80\x99re likely to be called an indulgent elitist who wants to force Americans to pay more for their food and an anti-progressive nostalgic for a bygone era of family farms.'b'I  SUPPOSE, as a chef, I\xe2\x80\x99m guilty of being indulgent, but nothing like the over-indulgence of the farm bill. The meat we end up buying at the local farmers\xe2\x80\x99 market is relatively expensive because, through the workings of agricultural legislation, conventional meat prices are unnaturally low. I\xe2\x80\x99m talking about the big boys \xe2\x80\x94 the Smithfields, the Tysons and the Archer Daniels Midlands of the world \xe2\x80\x94 which the farm bill subsidizes in the form of direct payments for grain (their feed is then artificially cheap). In doing that, we indirectly subsidize industrial farms\xe2\x80\x99 pollution; the health care costs (associated with animals bursting with corn fat, or animals reared on a constant cocktail of antibiotics); and the costs of insuring these companies against food-borne illness (brought on by a system that\xe2\x80\x99s run amok \xe2\x80\x94 or should I say that runs in muck, with animals living in their own waste).'b'We need a farm bill that makes corporations internalize the costs they impose on society in the same way that they internalize their profits.'b'Some people argue that the desire to promote smaller, family-run local farms is gratuitously effete and nostalgic. That\xe2\x80\x99s just nonsense. It\xe2\x80\x99s the agriculture industry\xe2\x80\x99s mind-set \xe2\x80\x94 high on capital, chemistry and machines \xe2\x80\x94 that is actually old-fashioned. Just as the Industrial Revolution of factories with heavy machinery and billowing black smoke is yesterday\xe2\x80\x99s news, so too are our unsustainable farming operations. Nonetheless our legislators continue to marvel at how modern industrial farms have become, and to invest ever more of our tax dollars into them.'b'In place of these outmoded and untenable practices, we need a farm bill that promotes sustainable farming research. We need increased money for the existing Sustainable Agriculture Research and Education Program, as well as an overhauled version of the Initiative for Future Agriculture and Food Systems,  a competitive grants program introduced in 1998 whose financing has since disappeared. These organizations encourage and finance innovative technologies to profit, and empower, the independent farmer.'b'We also need to ensure more money for things like the Conservation Security Program. Unlike most conservation programs that take land out of production, this one offers financial support to farmers who cultivate their fields in an environmentally sustainable manner. But enrollment in this program has been severely restricted since its 2002 inception, in large part because of $4 billion in budget cuts. That\xe2\x80\x99s a 50 percent cut  in a program that supports the basic tenets of land, water and wildlife conservation \xe2\x80\x94 tenets that go hand in hand with small-scale, chemical-free and crop-diverse agriculture.'b'These are also the tenets that built the world\xe2\x80\x99s great cuisines \xe2\x80\x94 Chinese, Italian, peasant French, Indian. Good gastronomy evolved out of good farming \xe2\x80\x94 the best chefs have merely delivered on what farmers have worked out over several centuries. A tomato bursting with flavor, or an impossibly juicy leg of lamb, is no accident. If we\xe2\x80\x99re able to eventually clone that, great, but let\xe2\x80\x99s do it in the name of flavor, not corporate greed.'b'Right now, as members of Congress prepare to debate the details of the new farm bill, let\xe2\x80\x99s hope they allow the best examples of gastronomy to be their guide. Great farming, environmental stewardship and nutritious food will not be far behind.'b'An Op-Ed article on Dec. 28, about Gerald Ford during World War II, incorrectly described a ship he saw hit by a Japanese torpedo during the Battle of Leyte Gulf. The ship, the cruiser Canberra, was American, not Australian.'b'WHEN Cesar Rodriguez\xe2\x80\x99s stepdaughter missed several weeks of first grade in the spring of 2005, he convinced an investigator from the city Administration for Children\xe2\x80\x99s Services that his wife, pregnant with her sixth child, was simply overwhelmed. After he agreed to get the older children to school on time, the investigator arranged to buy the family a crib, a stroller and a high chair. And then she closed the case.'b'Months later, when the girl came to school with stitches and a black eye, Mr. Rodriguez told a doctor and children\xe2\x80\x99s services investigators that the injury was the result of an accident. Then he kept his family out of sight for a month. No one unlocked the door to his Brooklyn apartment when Children\xe2\x80\x99s Services came to call.'b'On the morning of Jan. 11, 2006, an investigator visited Mr. Rodriguez\xe2\x80\x99s building once again, and this time she had no trouble getting inside. An ambulance crew was there with the badly damaged body of 7-year-old Nixzmary Brown. And now Mr. Rodriguez and the girl\xe2\x80\x99s mother, Nixzaliz Santiago, are nearing  trials on  murder charges.'b'There had been reasons to suspect violence and deception in the Nixzmary Brown case, but investigators had not followed up on them. City officials have acknowledged breaches of protocol on the part of child protection workers and others who had seen evidence of the child\xe2\x80\x99s abuse, and they have since made valuable reforms in caseworker oversight.'b'Nonetheless, in trying to prevent the same kind of failures from happening again, it is important to look beyond this case to a larger problem with the laws that guide child protection. Some of the rules that caseworkers must follow do not accurately reflect the day-to-day reality of their work, and may even divert their attention from serious trouble.'b'Last year I spent several weeks with skilled child-protection workers looking into reports of abuse and neglect in East Harlem. The best of these professionals are trained skeptics with instinctive compassion. They spend their days and evenings in the toughest neighborhoods, in the homes of the poorest New Yorkers,  trying  to make sure children are safe. Most are women in their 20s who have bachelor\xe2\x80\x99s degrees and earn modest salaries. (Starting pay is $38,000.)'b'Situations involving brutal assaults are very rare. Most cases stem from pressures linked to poverty \xe2\x80\x94 including overcrowded housing, domestic violence, mental health problems and substance abuse.'b'I\xe2\x80\x99ve watched investigators help single mothers organize child care, buy furniture or seek orders of protection against abusive men. I saw one worker in East Harlem embrace a sobbing mother of two, as the woman contemplated the near impossibility of coming up with the rent after her violent lover moved out. Later that evening, the worker cajoled a 16-year-old to obey her probation rules, stay out of detention and help her grandmother keep her family together.'b'From January through May of last year, after Nixzmary Brown\xe2\x80\x99s death, a torrent of nearly 1,600 new cases of suspected abuse and neglect were reported each week to the Administration for Children\xe2\x80\x99s Services \xe2\x80\x94 48 percent more than usual. To this day, new names are added to case lists faster than old cases can be resolved.'b'About one-third of such reports turn out to raise valid concerns. Many turn out to be frivolous complaints made by former lovers, unhappy neighbors or meddlesome in-laws. Other reports \xe2\x80\x94 far too many, city officials say privately \xe2\x80\x94 come from school officials  who don\xe2\x80\x99t first reach out to families to find out why a child is missing school, hungry or poorly clothed.'b'A central purpose of child protection services is to ensure that no child is killed or endangered by vicious, soulless or oblivious adults. State laws aim to accomplish this by requiring caseworkers to meet strict investigative protocols. These include interviews with everyone in the household within 48 hours, as well as others involved with the family \xe2\x80\x94 but also stiff deadlines and multiple record checks with clinics and schools, and paperwork that includes dozens of pages of notes that must be filed in two separate data systems.'b'These rules make sense in cases like Nixzmary Brown\xe2\x80\x99s, in which there is reason to suspect harsh abuse. But in the great majority of cases, violence or extreme neglect is not the issue. And the rules impose a staggering burden of work that can distract investigators from more important tasks.'b'New York City needs to consider a two-tiered approach to child-protection services, similar to the ones that have  been tried with some success in states like Minnesota. In all cases, investigators should be required to follow the most basic procedures. They should see all the children in the household, and interview the adults. In instances where there is reason to suspect serious problems, teams of skillful, highly experienced investigators should dig deeper.'b'But most cases should be quickly passed on to workers who have the time to give families the support, resources and counseling they need.'b'With Iraq sliding off a cliff, and now tugging another 20,000 young Americans along as well, it\xe2\x80\x99s worth wrestling with a larger question: Why are we so awful at foreign policy?'b'Shirin Ebadi, the Iranian lawyer who won the Nobel Peace Prize, dropped by the other day, and she made the same point with characteristic bluntness. \xe2\x80\x9cIt amazes me that the U.S., with all its scientific accomplishments, is so shortsighted in its foreign policy,\xe2\x80\x9d she noted.'b'It is pathetic. We can go safely to the moon but not to Anbar Province. We can peer into the farthest reaches of the universe, but we fail to notice (until it\xe2\x80\x99s too late) that many Iraqis loathe us. We produce movies that delight audiences all over the world, but we can\xe2\x80\x99t devise a foreign policy that anybody likes.'b'And it\xe2\x80\x99s not just right-wing Republicans who are the problem. President Bush has been particularly myopic, but Democrats mired us in Vietnam: shortsightedness is a bipartisan tradition in foreign policy. Historically, we are often our own worst enemy.'b'Iraq is the example of the moment. We invaded, thinking that we would get a pro-American bulwark, cheap oil, long-term military bases and the gratitude of liberated Iraqis. Instead, we fought Iraq, and Iran won.'b'Speaking of which, look at Iran. In 1953, we helped overthrow the democratically elected prime minister, Mohammed Mossadegh, to achieve a more pro-Western government. That created tensions that led to the Iranian revolution of 1979 and the rise of mullahs with nuclear dreams. If it weren\xe2\x80\x99t for our own policies, Iran might well now have a pro-American government.'b'So why do we act so often against our own long-term interests? There are at least two reasons.'b'The first is that great powers always lumber about, stepping on toes, provoking resentments, and solving problems militarily simply because they have that capability. One of the great passages of Thucydides records how some 2,400 years ago Athens decided to wipe out the city of Melos because it could.'b'Likewise, in 1955, when Britain was the dominant player in the Middle East, it formed the Baghdad Pact, a military arrangement intended to protect British interests in the Middle East. Instead, the arrangement inflamed Arab nationalists, strengthened anti-British feeling and contributed to the fall of the Iraqi monarchy in 1958 \xe2\x80\x94 and, eventually, to the rise of Saddam.'b'The second reason is particular to the U.S.: We don\xe2\x80\x99t understand the world. The U.S. may owe its existence to prickly nationalist troublemakers like Sam Adams, but (partly because relatively few Americans have lived abroad) we are obtuse about the appeal of prickly nationalist troublemakers elsewhere. Like George III, we empower our enemies.'b'So what does all this have to do with the price of tea in Baghdad?'b'Once again the White House is seeking military solutions that are likely to rebound and hurt us. Sending more young Americans into that maelstrom may well have three consequences: inflaming Iraqi nationalism, bolstering Shiite and Sunni extremists alike, and killing more young Americans.'b'A U.S. military study in 1999, recently declassified and in the National Security Archive, concluded that even 400,000 American troops might not be able to stabilize a post-Saddam Iraq. The study emphasized the importance of diplomacy to engage Iraq\xe2\x80\x99s neighbors.'b'But President Bush is moving in the opposite direction. Most worrying, he is hinting at  engaging Syria and Iran not diplomatically but militarily. We are careering down a road that may ultimately lead to military strikes on Iran \xe2\x80\x94 a disaster.'b'What would a better strategy look like? A good bit like the one advocated by the Iraq Study Group. It would emphasize engaging neighbors, a big push for political compromises within Iraq, steps toward troop withdrawals and an intensive effort to achieve an Israeli-Palestinian peace. (Condi Rice is planning this last effort.)'b'Would this strategy work in Iraq? No one knows. But such a bipartisan plan might at least bring a bit of healing to the U.S.'b'Meanwhile, history comes around in other ways. The Rev. Bob Edgar, the general secretary of the National Council of Churches, recalls that as a young congressman in April 1975, he encountered a similar presidential request for a surge of troops. It was a demand by President Gerald Ford for more U.S. forces to stabilize Saigon.'b'A White House photo captures Ford conferring with two of the architects of that request: senior administration officials named Dick Cheney and Donald Rumsfeld.'b'Income inequality is on the rise. The rich are getting better at passing their advantages on to their kids. Lifestyle and values gaps are widening between the educated and uneducated. So the big issue is: Will Americans demand new policies to reverse these trends \xe2\x80\x94 to redistribute wealth, to provide greater economic security? Are we about to see a mass populist movement in this country?'b'Nobody was smarter on this subject than Seymour Martin Lipset, the eminent sociologist who died at 84 on New Year\xe2\x80\x99s Eve. Lipset had been a socialist in the hothouse atmosphere of City College during the 1940s, and though he later became a moderate Democrat, he continued to wonder, with some regret, why America never had a serious socialist movement, why America never adopted a European-style welfare state.'b'Lipset was aware of the structural and demographic answers to such questions. For example, racially diverse nations tend to have lower levels of social support than homogeneous ones. People don\xe2\x80\x99t feel as bound together when they are divided  on ethnic lines and are less likely to embrace mutual support programs. You can have diversity or a big welfare state. It\xe2\x80\x99s hard to have both.'b'But as he studied these matters, Lipset moved away from structural or demographic explanations (too many counterexamples). He drifted, as Tocqueville and Werner Sombart had before him, to values.'b'America never had a feudal past, so nobody has a sense of social place or class-consciousness, Lipset observed. Meanwhile, Americans have inherited from their Puritan forebears a sense that they have a spiritual obligation to rise and succeed.'b'Two great themes run through American history, Lipset wrote in his 1963 book \xe2\x80\x9cThe First New Nation\xe2\x80\x9d: achievement and equality. These are often in tension because when you leave unequally endowed people free to achieve, you get unequal results.'b'Though Lipset never quite put it this way, the clear message from his writings is that when achievement and equality clash in America, achievement wins. Or to be more precise, the achievement ethos reshapes the definition of equality. When Americans use the word \xe2\x80\x9cequality,\xe2\x80\x9d they really mean \xe2\x80\x9cfair opportunity.\xe2\x80\x9d When Americans use the word \xe2\x80\x9cfreedom,\xe2\x80\x9d they really mean \xe2\x80\x9copportunity.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Lipset was relentlessly empirical, and rested his conclusions on data as well as history and philosophy. He found that Americans have for centuries embraced individualistic, meritocratic, antistatist values, even at times when income inequality was greater than it is today.'b'Large majorities of Americans have always believed that individuals are responsible for their own success, Lipset reported, while people in other countries are much more likely to point to forces beyond individual control. Sixty-five percent of Americans believe hard work is the key to success; only 12 percent think luck plays a major role.'b'In his \xe2\x80\x9cAmerican Exceptionalism\xe2\x80\x9d (1996), Lipset pointed out that 78 percent of Americans endorse the view that \xe2\x80\x9cthe strength of this country today is mostly based on the success of American business.\xe2\x80\x9d Fewer than a third of all Americans believe the state has a responsibility to reduce income disparities, compared with 82 percent of Italians. Over 70 percent of Americans believe \xe2\x80\x9cindividuals should take more responsibility for providing for themselves\xe2\x80\x9d whereas most Japanese believe \xe2\x80\x9cthe state should take more responsibility to ensure everyone is provided for.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'America, he concluded, is an outlier, an exceptional nation. And though his patriotism pervaded his writing, he emphasized that American exceptionalism is \xe2\x80\x9ca double-edged sword.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Political movements that run afoul of these individualistic, achievement-oriented values rarely prosper. The Democratic Party is now divided between moderates \xe2\x80\x94 who emphasize individual responsibility and education to ameliorate inequality \xe2\x80\x94 and progressive populists, who advocate an activist state that will protect people from forces beyond their control. Given the deep forces in American history, the centrists will almost certainly win out.'b'Indeed, the most amazing thing about the past week is how modest the Democratic agenda has been. Democrats have been out of power in Congress for 12 years. They finally get a chance to legislate and they push through a series of small proposals that are little pebbles compared to the vast economic problems they described during the campaign.'b'They grasp the realities Marty Lipset described. They understand that in the face of inequality, Americans have usually opted for policies that offer more opportunity, not those emphasizing security or redistribution. American domestic policy is drifting leftward, but there are sharp limits on how far it will go.'b'To the Editor:'b'I\xe2\x80\x99d like to note my objections to both the premise and substance of \xe2\x80\x9c'b'How to End Long Island\xe2\x80\x99s Sour Vintages'b',\xe2\x80\x9d by Lisa Granik (Op-Ed, Jan. 7).'b'There may be other factors such as illness and old age that weigh into an owner\xe2\x80\x99s decision to sell a vineyard property. They receive committee assignments that can earn them as much as $40,000 on top of their $79,000 yearly salary, and their district lines are rigged in their favor for lifetime job security. Dir., Legal Services of the Hudson Valley 'b'White Plains'b''b''b''b'Gratefully Received, Suddenly Rescinded'b''b'To the Editor:'b'I read \xe2\x80\x9c'b'Scraping the Bottom of the Albany Pork Barrel'b'\xe2\x80\x9d (Dec. 31) with great interest. Spano.'b'Surprise, surprise \xe2\x80\x94 we recently were informed by the New York State Department of Agriculture and Markets that our grant had been rescinded. Apparently retaliating against the loser is seen as a fair strategy, regardless of the disappointed but deserving constituents.'b'Reforming the system to level the playing field so that discretionary spending is equally available within districts and once pledged, cannot be withdrawn, would certainly be a step in the right direction.'b'Deborah Mehne'b'Chairwoman'b'SPCA of Westchester'b'Briarcliff Manor'b''b''b''b'Birmingham, Ala.'b'Jack Cline is in a hospital here fighting for his life, stricken by leukemia that he says he got from exposure to benzene at his factory job. In most states, he would be able to sue the companies that made the benzene. But Alabama\xe2\x80\x99s all-Republican, wildly pro-business Supreme Court threw out his case.'b'In a ruling that would have done  Kafka proud, the court held that there was never a valid time for Mr. Cline to sue. If he had sued when he was exposed to the benzene, it would have been too early. Alabama law requires people exposed to dangerous chemicals to wait until a \xe2\x80\x9cmanifest\xe2\x80\x9d injury develops. But when his leukemia developed years later, it was too late. Alabama\xe2\x80\x99s statute of limitations requires that suits be brought within two years of exposure.'b'Mr. Cline, who says God has kept him alive so he can challenge the unfairness of Alabama\xe2\x80\x99s law, told his lawyer, Robert Palmer, to keep fighting. Mr. Palmer started a statewide petition drive, wrote a flurry of op-ed pieces and asked the court to reconsider. In an extraordinary move, it reopened the case and heard new arguments last spring.'b'Big business and its allies are loudly promoting \xe2\x80\x9ctort reform\xe2\x80\x9d by arguing that America is drowning in frivolous lawsuits. They are winning the public relations battle. Everyone knows the story of the woman who sued McDonald\xe2\x80\x99s because she was burned by hot coffee. But few people know of the Jack Clines \xe2\x80\x94 and there are many of them \xe2\x80\x94 who have been denied their day in court.'b'Corporate America \xe2\x80\x94 with its large contributions to political and judicial candidates, and its top-dollar lobbyists \xe2\x80\x94 has had remarkable success persuading legislatures and courts to erode the bedrock principle of civil law: when people are injured, they are entitled to sue for damages.'b'At the top of industry\xe2\x80\x99s list of tactics is immunity \xe2\x80\x94 the rather brazen notion that companies should be shielded from lawsuits no matter how negligently or dishonestly they act. Gun makers and dealers, notoriously, persuaded Congress in 2005 to give them immunity when their guns are used to maim and kill.'b'Industries are also winning immunity at the state level, and attracting far less attention. Pharmaceutical companies pushed through a law in Michigan protecting them when their drugs injure or kill people, as long as the drugs were approved by the Food and Drug Administration. There is no reason F.D.A. approval, a deeply flawed process, should be a shield.'b'When corporations do end up in court, they have lowered the stakes substantially by undermining punitive damages, which have long been one of the main ways that society deters people from unreasonably putting others at risk. The United States Supreme Court struck a major blow against punitive damages a decade ago, ruling that it was unconstitutional for a jury to award $2 million in punitive damages against an auto dealer that knowingly sold a damaged, repainted BMW as new.'b'Lower federal court judges, many of whom have been screened by the Bush administration for pro-business sympathies, and state court judges, many of whose campaigns were bankrolled by big business, are eagerly joining in. So are state legislatures. Last month Ohio\xe2\x80\x99s legislature voted to cap punitive damages in many cases against paint companies \xe2\x80\x94 which have been accused of selling lead-based paint that causes retardation in children \xe2\x80\x94 at a paltry $5,000.'b'Perhaps the most insidious tactic for slamming the courthouse door on injured people is the stealth use of \xe2\x80\x9cpre-emption.\xe2\x80\x9d When federal and state laws conflict, the federal law pre-empts, or invalidates, the state law. The Bush administration is taking advantage of this principle by issuing weak regulations in a wide range of areas to wipe out stronger state-law protections. When people try to sue, they may find that their legal rights have been swept away. Among the areas the administration has focused on are automobile roof crushes and mattress flammability.'b'These incursions on the right to sue, taken together, are a serious assault on justice. In the most extreme cases, they may also be unconstitutional. Mr. Cline\xe2\x80\x99s lawyer, Mr. Palmer, argued that preventing him from ever suing denied him his rights under the Alabama Constitution to seek a legal remedy for his injuries.'b'Mr. Palmer was encouraged when the Alabama Supreme Court reopened the case. He also saw it as a good sign when it scheduled oral arguments for a special public session on a law school campus, an indication it considered the case particularly significant. The arguments went well. \xe2\x80\x9cQuestions asked by several justices indicated they were troubled by the legal Catch-22,\xe2\x80\x9d The Birmingham News reported.'b'The court ruled this month. It affirmed the dismissal of Mr. Cline\xe2\x80\x99s case by a 5-to-4 vote. If Mr. Cline wanted to challenge the unfairness of the rules, it said, he would have to take it up with the State Legislature \xe2\x80\x94 a body every bit as pro-business as the Alabama Supreme Court.'b'Mr. Palmer intends to take the case to the United States Supreme Court. In the meantime, Mr. Cline can take some small comfort in the close vote. Four Alabama justices, at least, would not accept a legal system that told people like him that \xe2\x80\x9cno matter when\xe2\x80\x9d they \xe2\x80\x9cfile the action, it is either too soon or too late.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Many Connecticut residents experienced the annoying necessity this past Christmas Eve and New Year\xe2\x80\x99s Eve of having to act like bootleggers in order to serve alcohol at parties. Those who had not planned ahead were forced to drive to border states to purchase wine, beer and other spirits. The reason? This year, both days, normally among the strongest for liquor sales, fell on Sundays, when it is illegal to sell alcohol in Connecticut.'b'There are many worse fates, of course, but the tyranny of the calendar combined with the state\xe2\x80\x99s enduring Sunday closing law forced people to scramble to out-of-state stores. Connecticut clings to the Puritan tradition of a Sunday ban, in part because many mom-and-pop establishments, which like to stay closed on Sunday, have fought to keep it.'b'But in the past few years alone a dozen states have done away with the Sunday booze ban. Even Massachusetts, which started the practice nearly 400 years ago, has ditched the tradition. States like Massachusetts, Rhode Island and New York, which border Connecticut, are now cashing in on the Nutmeg State\xe2\x80\x99s stubborn attachment to an inconvenient and inessential law.'b'One consolation is that this year, Christmas Eve and New Year\xe2\x80\x99s Eve are on Mondays, and they will not fall again on Sundays until 2017, by which time the legislature may have come to its senses.'b'It was surreal how disconnected President Bush was the other night, both from Iraq\xe2\x80\x99s horrifying reality and America\xe2\x80\x99s anguish over this unnecessary, mismanaged and now unwinnable war. Indeed, most Americans seem far ahead of the president. They understand that what the country urgently needs is for Mr. Bush to chart a way out of Iraq that also limits the chaos that will be left behind.'b'The president\xe2\x80\x99s disconnect goes far to explain the harshly critical reaction of Congress and the public to his plan to further bleed America\xe2\x80\x99s overstretched forces by sending some 20,000 additional troops in an attempt to impose peace on Baghdad\xe2\x80\x99s vengeful streets. He proposes to do that without any enforceable commitments from the Iraqi government that it will take the necessary political steps that are the only hope for tamping down a spiraling civil war.'b'There are no really satisfying answers in Iraq, since all of the remaining options are bad. Still, some are notably worse than others, and Mr. Bush has come up with possibly the worst. He would mortgage thousands more American lives and what remains of Washington\xe2\x80\x99s credibility in the region to a destructively sectarian Shiite government that he seems unwilling or unable to influence or restrain.'b'\xe2\x80\xa2'b'Unlike Mr. Bush\xe2\x80\x99s views on the American military presence in Iraq, our views have evolved as the evident realities on the ground have changed. At the outset, although we opposed Mr. Bush\xe2\x80\x99s invasion, we hoped the United States military could provide enough security to allow an elected government to build the foundations of national unity and eventual democracy.'b'As it became increasingly clear that Iraqi political leaders had other, less noble intentions, we still hoped that a substantial American military presence could be used to shield innocent civilians from the growing violence, train reliable and professional Iraqi security forces to take over that task, and exert leverage on Iraqi leaders to follow a less divisive and destructive course.'b'Now, with Mr. Bush unwilling or unable to persuade Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki to take the minimum steps necessary to justify any deeper American commitment, we recognize that even that has become unrealistic. Mr. Maliki gave the latest White House plan an even chillier reception than it received in the United States Congress, boycotting a Thursday news conference in Baghdad announcing it. He apparently would have preferred to see American forces sent to fight Sunni insurgents in western Anbar Province, leaving Baghdad as a free-fire zone for his Shiite militia partners.'b'But even knowing all that, America cannot simply wash its hands of Iraq and go home. The region\xe2\x80\x99s problems, many of them made worse by this war, are unavoidably America\xe2\x80\x99s problems as well. For starters, Iraq is in imminent danger of violently breaking apart, driving millions of refugees across its borders \xe2\x80\x94 who will bring with them their ethnic grievances, and in some cases their weapons \xe2\x80\x94 and potentially unleashing a chain reaction of regional conflicts that could draw in Turkey, Saudi Arabia, Iran and perhaps others as well.'b'\xe2\x80\xa2'b'Whatever else happens, Iran has already become more formidable and dangerous. Where it once had a hostile Saddam Hussein on its western border, it now has a friendly Shiite fundamentalist government. Its other longtime enemy, the United States, has had its diplomatic and military clout  severely diminished by this war.'b'The expanding power of a revolutionary, Shiite Iran is profoundly unsettling to the conservative Sunni-led governments in most of the Arab Middle East, which have been America\xe2\x80\x99s traditional allies in the region. If the United States is to recoup any of its standing and influence there, it will have to find a way to contain the chaos in Iraq. Incarcerating people in overcrowded facilities is inhumane and always expensive: it costs $29,500 a year to imprison each person. This problem did not develop overnight. The prison population rose steadily from the late 1980s until 2003. And the recent increase is not surprising, especially in light of last year\xe2\x80\x99s rising crime rate. But the important thing to remember is that prison is not an answer to crime; bigger prison populations reflect society\xe2\x80\x99s failure to find answers.'b'The state needs to walk a difficult tightrope: reducing the number of inmates in prison while keeping dangerous offenders off the streets. Connecticut is one of the few states to mix the two age groups for serious crimes. Housing young people with career criminals is bad public policy. Continuing the status quo when prisons are overcrowded makes even less sense. The current conditions add urgency to the need to house young offenders in separate facilities, and not treat them as adults.'b'Connecticut prisons may be overcrowded, but building more of them is the last thing we need. Last month in Florida, the head of the state\xe2\x80\x99s social services department  resigned abruptly after having been fined $80,000 and is facing criminal contempt charges for failing to transfer severely mentally ill jail inmates to state hospitals.'b'Ten days ago, the Supreme Court agreed to determine when mentally ill death row inmates should be considered so  deranged that their execution would be constitutionally impermissible. The case involves a 48-year-old Navy veteran who is a diagnosed schizophrenic. In the decade leading up to the crime he was hospitalized 14 times for severe mental illness.'b'According to a study released by the Justice Department in September, 56 percent of jail inmates in state prisons and 64 percent of inmates across the country reported mental health problems within the past year.'b'Though troubling, none of this should come as a surprise. Over the past 40 years, the United States dismantled a colossal mental health complex and rebuilt \xe2\x80\x94 bed by bed \xe2\x80\x94 an enormous prison. During the 20th century we exhibited a schizophrenic relationship to deviance.'b'After more than 50 years of stability, federal and state prison populations skyrocketed  from under 200,000 persons in 1970 to more than 1.3 million in 2002. That year, our imprisonment rate rose above 600 inmates per 100,000 adults. With the inclusion of an additional 700,000  inmates in jail, we now incarcerate more than two  million people \xe2\x80\x94 resulting in the highest incarceration number and rate in the world, five times that of Britain and 12 times that of Japan.'b'What few people realize, though, is that in the 1940s and \xe2\x80\x9950s we institutionalized people at even higher rates \xe2\x80\x94 only it was in mental hospitals and asylums. Simply put, when the data on state and county mental hospitalization rates are combined with the data on prison rates for 1928 through 2000, the imprisonment revolution of the late 20th century barely reaches the level we experienced at mid-century. Our current culture of control is by no means new.'b'The graph on the left \xe2\x80\x94 based on statistics from the federal Census Bureau, Department of Health and Human Services and Bureau of Justice Statistics \xe2\x80\x94 shows the aggregate rate of institutionalization per 100,000 adults in the United States from 1928 to 2000, as well as the disaggregated trend lines for mental hospitalization on the one hand and state and federal prisons on the other.'b'The numbers include only state and county mental hospitals. There were many more kinds of mental institutions at mid-century, ones for \xe2\x80\x9cmental defectives and epileptics\xe2\x80\x9d and the mentally retarded, psychiatric wards in veterans  hospitals, as well as \xe2\x80\x9cpsychopathic\xe2\x80\x9d and private mental hospitals. If we include residents of those facilities, from  1935 to  1963 the United States consistently institutionalized at rates well above 700 per 100,000 adults \xe2\x80\x94 with highs of 778 in 1939 and 786 in 1955. It should be clear why there is such a large proportion of mentally ill persons in our prisons: individuals who used to be tracked for mental health treatment are now getting a one-way ticket to jail.'b'Of course, there are important demographic differences between the two populations. In 1937, women represented 48 percent of residents in state mental hospitals. In contrast, new prison admissions have consistently been 95 percent male. Also, the mental health patients from the 1930s to the 1960s were older and whiter than  prison inmates of the 1990s.'b'But the graph poses a number of troubling questions: Why did we diagnose deviance in such radically different ways over the course of the 20th century? Do we need to be imprisoning at such high rates, or were we right, 50 years ago, to hospitalize instead? Why were so many women hospitalized? Why have they been replaced by young black men? Have both prisons and mental hospitals included large numbers of unnecessarily incarcerated individuals?'b'Whatever the answers, the pendulum has swung too far \xe2\x80\x94 possibly off its hinges.'b'It would be na\xc3\xafve, today, to address any of these questions without also considering the impact of imprisonment on crime. One of the most reliable studies estimates that the increased prison population over the 1990s accounted for about a third of the overall drop in crime that decade.'b'However, prisons are not the only institutions that seem to have this effect. In a recent study, I demonstrated that the rate of institutionalization \xe2\x80\x94 including mental hospitals \xe2\x80\x94 was a far better predictor of serious violent crime from 1926 to 2000 than just prison populations. The data reveal a robust negative relationship between overall institutionalization (prisons and asylums) and homicide. Preliminary findings based on state-level panel data confirm these results.'b'The effect on crime may not depend on whether the institution is a mental hospital or a prison. Even from a crime-fighting perspective, then, it is time to rethink our prison and mental health policies. A lot more work must be done before proposing answers to those troubling questions. But the first step is to realize that we have been wildly erratic in our approach to deviance, mental health and the prison.'b'With corporations posting record profits amid nonstop accounting scandals, one would assume that the Internal Revenue Service is looking long and hard at big companies\xe2\x80\x99  tax returns. Unfortunately, the opposite is true.'b'Since 2003, I.R.S policy has called for spending less time on any one large corporate audit, with the purported aim of auditing more big businesses. But as The Times\xe2\x80\x99s David Cay Johnston reported last week, I.R.S. auditors are being pushed by the agency\xe2\x80\x99s top officials to prematurely close audits of large corporations with agreements that they  pay only  a fraction of the additional taxes that could be collected. Dozens of auditors said they were instructed to limit their examinations to issues that the I.R.S. and the  companies agreed to in advance, even if suspicious deductions or other questionable tax tactics emerged during the audit.'b'Recently released I.R.S statistics \xe2\x80\x94 which the agency is required to disclose, but which it had long withheld \xe2\x80\x94 underscore Mr. Johnston\xe2\x80\x99s report. In 2006, the time devoted to each large-company audit was nearly 21 percent below what it was in 2002. From 2003 through 2005, an ever larger share of companies was audited; but in 2006, the share declined from a high of 44 percent in 2005, to 34 percent, about where it was in 2002.'b'The I.R.S. says its light-touch approach is  successful because auditors are finding much more tax owed for each hour they work than they did in 2002. But auditors interviewed by Mr. Johnston dispute that claim. They say that abusive and illegal tax shelters have become so pervasive that it\xe2\x80\x99s easy to find additional taxes due. So the overall figure rises, even though companies are being allowed to pay far less than they owe. Economists and tax experts who have looked at the I.R.S. statistics have also raised the possibility that an increase in corporate noncompliance is behind the increased tax-due amounts, not more effective auditing.'b'Congress must ensure that the agency  justifies its policy or changes it.'b'The Bush administration has appointed an extreme political partisan as the new United States  attorney for Arkansas. But even after the Gulag was largely shut down, the Communist state demanded constant and total fealty. The levers were fear and total control over every aspect of every life. The price ranged from silence, passivity and marching in the May Day parade all the way to informing and active collusion.'b'In his book about the legacies of World War II in Germany and Japan, \xe2\x80\x9cThe Wages of Guilt,\xe2\x80\x9d Ian Buruma wrote that it was not the resistance heroes who fascinated him as a youth in Holland during the war, but the \xe2\x80\x9cfrightened man who betrayed to save his life, who looked the other way, who grasped the wrong horn of a hideous moral dilemma.\xe2\x80\x9d I had that same reaction when I was a correspondent in the Soviet Union, perhaps because, like Mr. Buruma, I could never be sure which horn I would have grasped in that life.'b'Of course there were villains, people who enrolled in the system for the power, who reveled in humiliating and persecuting the helpless. Kennesaw\xe2\x80\x99s crime dropped sharply, while Morton Grove\xe2\x80\x99s did not.'b'To some degree, this is rational. Criminals, unsurprisingly, would rather break into a house where they aren\xe2\x80\x99t at risk of being shot. As David Kopel noted in a 2001 article in The Arizona Law Review, burglars report that they try to avoid homes where armed residents are likely to be present. We see this phenomenon internationally, too, with the United States having a lower proportion of \xe2\x80\x9chot\xe2\x80\x9d burglaries \xe2\x80\x94 break-ins where the burglars know the home to be occupied \xe2\x80\x94 than countries with restrictive gun laws.'b'Likewise, in the event of disasters that leave law enforcement overwhelmed, armed citizens can play an important role in stanching crime. And the two rival formats for high-definition video on disc \xe2\x80\x94 HD-DVD and Blu-ray \xe2\x80\x94 are equipped with even more sophisticated copy-prevention technology.'b'Americans pay significant monthly fees to enjoy cable television, but cable companies also tightly control all of their content. Cable companies want to make sure that the only way for consumers to get their hands on CableCards is to buy them directly from cable companies.'b'Even children are bothered by the increasing restrictions. One electronics show attendee told me his 12-year-old recently asked him, \xe2\x80\x9cWhy do I have to buy my favorite game five times?\xe2\x80\x9d Because the company that made the game wants to profit from each device the user plays it on: Wii, Xbox, PlayStation, Game Boy or phone.'b'At this year\xe2\x80\x99s show, the president of the Consumer Electronics Association, Gary Shapiro, spoke up for \xe2\x80\x9cdigital freedom,\xe2\x80\x9d arguing that tech companies shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t need Hollywood\xe2\x80\x99s permission when they design a new product. Consumers, he said, should have the right to enjoy the content they buy at whatever time and on whichever device they like. They should also enjoy \xe2\x80\x9cfair use\xe2\x80\x9d to the extent that they can, without asking, copy movies for themselves, or copy a few seconds of a song and post it on a personal Web page.'b'If consumer electronics companies won\xe2\x80\x99t give us these freedoms, there is a good chance we will find a way to take them for ourselves. Every form of digital rights management ever invented has proved vulnerable. Just weeks ago, a hacker unlocked the supposedly perfect HD-DVD encryption scheme.'b'The question is whether, in the face of economic and legal pressure from entertainment companies, next year\xe2\x80\x99s Consumer Electronics Show will have anything new at all.'b'Stanford, Calif.'b'CARBON DIOXIDE is heating up the Earth. Ice caps are melting, ocean levels are rising, hurricanes are intensifying, tropical diseases are spreading and the threat of droughts, floods and famines looms large. Can planting a tree help stop all this from happening?'b'To some, it\xe2\x80\x99s a no-brainer: We add carbon dioxide to the atmosphere every time we use energy from coal, oil or gas; but each tree can remove more than a ton of carbon dioxide from the atmosphere over its lifetime. Based on this logic, it might seem a good idea to go out and plant a tree to slow global heating.'b'And if you don\xe2\x80\x99t have the time, projects have sprung up throughout the world claiming to help cool the earth, ready to accept your money and plant a tree in your name. The computer company Dell will now donate $2 from every laptop sale to planting trees in an effort to offset the carbon dioxide emissions that result from powering their computers. For a 2 percent to 4 percent surcharge on bills, Pacific Gas and Electric will offer to offset its customers\xe2\x80\x99 carbon emissions by helping to preserve California\xe2\x80\x99s carbon-storing forests.'b'While preserving and restoring forests is unquestionably good for the natural environment, new scientific studies are concluding that preservation and restoration of forests outside the tropics will do little or nothing to help slow climate change. And some projects intended to slow the heating of the planet may be accelerating it instead.'b'Trees don\xe2\x80\x99t just absorb carbon dioxide \xe2\x80\x94 they soak up the sun\xe2\x80\x99s heating rays, too. Forests tend to be darker than farms and pastures and therefore tend to absorb more sunlight. This has a warming influence that appears to cancel, on average, the cooling influence of the forest\xe2\x80\x99s carbon storage. This effect is most pronounced in snowy areas \xe2\x80\x94 snow on bare ground reflects far more sunlight back to space than does a snowed-in forest \xe2\x80\x94 so forests in areas with seasonal snow cover can be strongly warming.'b'In contrast, tropical forests appear to be doubly valuable to the earth\xe2\x80\x99s climate system. Not only do they store copious amounts of carbon, the roots of tropical trees reach down deep, drawing up water that they evaporate through their leaves. In the atmosphere, this water may form clouds that reflect sunlight back to space, helping to cool the earth.'b'These findings have important policy implications. It has been suggested that agreements to limit climate change should consider carbon stored in forests. If so, they would need to consider the direct climate effects of forests so as to avoid perverse incentives to plant warming forests in places like the United States, Canada, Europe and the former Soviet Union. However, tropical forests, which are generally found in developing countries, may be due a double climate credit \xe2\x80\x94 one for their carbon storage and another for their cooling clouds.'b'What does this mean for local reforestation efforts? Consider Pacific Gas and Electric\xe2\x80\x99s surcharge plan. While the carbon soaked up by California\xe2\x80\x99s forests reduces atmospheric carbon dioxide concentrations everywhere, cooling Crete, Canc\xc3\xban and Calcutta, the sunlight they absorb warms the state and the surrounding region. So, it might even cool us if we were to cut down those dark forests. Lumber interests might look gleefully upon the prospect.'b'Clear-cutting mountains to slow climate change is, of course, nuts. The broadest goal is neither to slow the growth of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere nor to slow climate change, but rather to preserve the irreplaceable natural balance that sustains life as we know it on this planet. We want to avoid climate change so that we might pass these diverse natural riches on to future generations. In this light, preserving and restoring forests is a valuable activity, regardless of its impact on climate \xe2\x80\x94 we need more trees, not fewer.'b'But the notion that we can save the planet just by planting trees is a dangerous illusion. To preserve our environment, we must drastically reduce carbon dioxide emissions, and this will require a major transformation of our energy system. A primary goal for the next half-century should be to transform our energy system to one based on clean, safe and environmentally acceptable energy sources like wind, solar and perhaps nuclear. This means solving the real problems involved with storing and distributing power, providing energy for transportation, and using nuclear plants.'b'We cannot afford to indulge ourselves with well-intentioned activities that do little to solve the underlying problem. Instead, we must demand that our political leaders do more to revolutionize our energy system and preserve our environmental inheritance for future generations.'b'And then we can plant a tree.'b'Nixzmary Brown was just 7 when she died, one year ago this month in Brooklyn, an apparent victim of brutality at home and neglect by the child welfare system. The 2010 census should include a test run at counting the nation\xe2\x80\x99s 1.4 million prison inmates at their permanent addresses instead of in prisons. That would help bring an end to a corrosive but little known practice that distorts the political process in virtually every corner of the country.'b'Inmates are denied the right to vote in all but two states. But state lawmakers treat them as residents of the prisons when drawing legislative maps, to inflate the head count in lightly populated rural areas where prisons are typically built. A nursing home works well for short-term recovery. But for long-term care, couldn\xe2\x80\x99t we imagine a better way to spend that $75,000?'b'What about simply staying home and paying for the needed medical services \xc3\xa0 la carte? That would be expensive. The average charge for a health aide is $19 per hour. So to keep someone with you around the clock for a year would cost at least $166,000, more than double your $75,000.'b'But three frail elderly people could share an apartment and a 24-hour aide and, by pooling the cost, have more than $58,000 left over among them for food, clothing, shelter, physical therapy and even fun and frolic.'b'In many cases, a nursing home offers services far beyond what a patient needs. Many people need only a little help \xe2\x80\x94 someone to dispense their medicines, prepare their meals and help them get in and out of bed. Others might need 24-hour care, but not a nursing home.'b'Assisted living \xe2\x80\x94 the halfway house between home-sweet-home and the nursing home \xe2\x80\x94 would fit the bill. But Medicaid won\xe2\x80\x99t pay for assisted living. Medicaid will pay only for care in medical facilities, and assisted living doesn\xe2\x80\x99t qualify, even though the average annual cost is significantly lower, about $35,000.'b'The generally accepted gold standard for health care is to provide services in the least restrictive environment. Unnecessarily shuttling people into the most restrictive setting grossly violates this standard.'b'The idea of pooled resources and cooperative living arrangements is not new, nor does it originate in elder care. In 1963, George Fairweather, a psychologist, created \xe2\x80\x9ccommunity lodges,\xe2\x80\x9d where psychiatric patients could live cooperatively outside hospitals. Groups of patients would pool their government benefits, buy or rent lodging and hire professionals to meet their special needs. Today, lodge programs modeled on this concept exist across the nation, enabling psychiatric patients to have control of their own lives.'b'Aging at home is an idea that has an intrinsic appeal to my iconoclastic baby-boom generation. We are faced with a public health system that resists innovation, but the sheer size of our generation may force the issue. Everyone is worrying about how the diminutive X, Y and Z generations will pay for all of us in our dotage. Financial shortfalls may divert money into more cost-effective, less restrictive, more consumer-controlled environments for the elderly who need help.'b'And that would be a stroke of good luck for all of us.'b'The one crucial assumption behind everything President Bush proposed on Iraq last week was that Washington would have the wholehearted support of Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki. None of Mr. Bush\xe2\x80\x99s ideas  \xe2\x80\x94 his plan to send more American soldiers to fight alongside Iraqi units in Baghdad, his program for jump-starting the Iraqi economy, his hope of reconciling rival sectarian communities and heading off civil war  \xe2\x80\x94 can possibly succeed without the full cooperation of the Iraqi government.'b'Yet in the days following Mr. Bush\xe2\x80\x99s address, as in the days before, Mr. Maliki has demonstrated how far his own goals diverge from America\xe2\x80\x99s best interests or any reasonable path for containing Iraq\xe2\x80\x99s civil war. Consider, for example, Mr. Maliki\xe2\x80\x99s designation of Lt. Gen. Aboud Qanbar \xe2\x80\x94 a Shiite officer known for his combative resistance to American tutelage \xe2\x80\x94 to be the overall military commander of the new Baghdad security drive.'b'Any hope that this campaign will prove more effective than past failed efforts depends on soldiers\xe2\x80\x99  being able to finally move against Shiite militias. If General Qanbar and Mr. Maliki plan to continue shielding militias like the Mahdi Army, this new drive will be doomed before it begins.'b'What another failure would mean was underscored in a particularly grim way yesterday when the United Nations reported that some 34,000 Iraqi civilians died violently last year, a staggering number in a country of less than 27 million people. Yesterday, more than 100 Iraqis died in Baghdad alone.'b'Consider also the grisly decapitation over the weekend of Barzan Ibrahim al-Tikriti, Saddam Hussein\xe2\x80\x99s co-defendant and half brother.  Two weeks of watching how the lynch mob atmosphere of Mr. Hussein\xe2\x80\x99s execution instantly turned a monster into a martyr throughout the Sunni Arab world should have put Mr. Maliki on notice to get this one right. But whether deliberately or through breathtaking incompetence, the Iraqi government did not get it right, once again fanning sectarian flames.'b'Unless President Bush insists that Mr. Maliki accept specific and enforceable policy benchmarks and timelines \xe2\x80\x94 starting with the disarming of sectarian militias \xe2\x80\x94 the United States will remain hostage to the Iraqi prime minister and his radical Shiite agenda.'b'Mr. Bush needs to make clear to the Iraqi leader that continued American support will depend on his active cooperation. And that, ultimately, the Iraqis have even more to lose than the Americans from an unending civil war.'b'To the Editor:'b'Re \xe2\x80\x9cPassing Exchange Becomes Political Flashpoint Focused on Feminism\xe2\x80\x9d (news article, Jan. 13):'b'The silliness resulting from Senator Barbara Boxer\xe2\x80\x99s comment to Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9cWho pays the price?\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 is nothing more than that: silliness.'b'Neither of these women has family members who are in the military waiting to be sent to Iraq or who are already there.
