But a small group of victims\xe2\x80\x99 families has regrettably decided to mount a public campaign against the compromise.'b'They are trying to discourage contributions to the memorial until the victims\xe2\x80\x99 names appear exactly the way they want them, listing the age, corporate affiliation and floor on which each person  worked. We fear that this effort will only add to the distress of other families who have been waiting for years for what is, after all, a public memorial.'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s hard to imagine a group of people who have been listened to more intently than this group of family members. Their views have helped to shape or reshape nearly every aspect of the redevelopment of ground zero \xe2\x80\x94 and especially the memorial. They had George Pataki\xe2\x80\x99s ear when he was governor,  and they succeeded in shaping the debate about ground zero in ways that were sometimes polarizing. Out of respect for their loss, everyone has listened to them and tried to address their concerns.'b'But ground zero cannot be turned into a private memorial. If Cantor Fitzgerald, for example, feels it is important to create its own separate memorial to its terrible loss on that day, it should certainly do so. But the public memorial must be more expansive than that. There is a stark beauty and essential simplicity to the proposed listing of names as it now stands. It honors the nature of public memory, as well as the role the 9/11 museum will play in telling a fuller history of that day.'b'As painful as the private loss of this small group of mourners is, it must be accommodated as part of the larger public loss.'b'For those hoping for real action on global warming and energy policy, the State of the Union address was a downer. There had been hints and hopes that the speech would be a Nixon-goes-to-China moment, with President Bush turning conservationist. But it ended up being more of a Nixon-bombs-Cambodia moment.'b'Too bad: the rumors were tantalizing. Al Hubbard, the chairman of the National Economic Council, predicted \xe2\x80\x9cheadlines above the fold that will knock your socks off in terms of our commitment to energy independence.\xe2\x80\x9d British officials told the newspaper The Observer that Mr. Bush would \xe2\x80\x9cmake a historic shift in his position on global warming.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'None of it happened. Mr. Bush acknowledged that climate change is a problem, but you missed it if you sneezed. He said something vague about fuel economy, but the White House fact sheet on energy makes it clear that there was even less there than met the ear.'b'The only real substance was Mr. Bush\xe2\x80\x99s call for a huge increase in the supply of \xe2\x80\x9calternative fuels.\xe2\x80\x9d Mainly that means using ethanol  to replace gasoline. Unfortunately, that\xe2\x80\x99s a really bad idea.'b'There is a place for ethanol in the world\xe2\x80\x99s energy future  \xe2\x80\x94  but that place is in the tropics. Brazil has managed to replace a lot of its gasoline consumption with ethanol. But Brazil\xe2\x80\x99s ethanol comes from sugar cane.'b'In the United States, ethanol comes overwhelmingly from corn, a much less suitable raw material. In fact, corn is such a poor source of ethanol that researchers at the University of Minnesota estimate that converting the entire U.S. corn crop  \xe2\x80\x94  the sum of all our ears  \xe2\x80\x94  into ethanol would replace only 12 percent of our gasoline consumption.'b'Still, doesn\xe2\x80\x99t every little bit help? Well, this little bit would come at a very high price compared with the obvious alternative  \xe2\x80\x94  conservation. The Congressional Budget Office estimates that reducing gasoline consumption 10 percent through an increase in fuel economy standards would cost producers and consumers about $3.6 billion a year. Achieving the same result by expanding ethanol production would cost taxpayers at least $10 billion a year, based on the subsidies ethanol already receives  \xe2\x80\x94  and probably much more, because expanding production would require higher subsidies.'b'What\xe2\x80\x99s more, ethanol production has hidden costs. Even the Department of Energy, which is relatively optimistic, says that the net energy savings from replacing a gallon of gasoline with ethanol are only the equivalent of about a quarter of a gallon, because of the energy used to grow corn, transport it, run ethanol plants, and so on. And these energy inputs come almost entirely from fossil fuels, so it\xe2\x80\x99s not clear whether promoting ethanol does anything to reduce carbon dioxide emissions.'b'So why is ethanol, not conservation, the centerpiece of the administration\xe2\x80\x99s energy policy? Actually, it\xe2\x80\x99s not entirely Mr. Bush\xe2\x80\x99s fault.'b'To be sure, at this point Mr. Bush\xe2\x80\x99s people seem less concerned with devising good policy than with finding something, anything, for the president to talk about that doesn\xe2\x80\x99t end with the letter \xe2\x80\x9cq.\xe2\x80\x9d And the malign influence of Dick \xe2\x80\x9cSign of Personal Virtue\xe2\x80\x9d Cheney, who no  doubt still sneers at  conservation,  continues to hang over everything.'b'But even after the Bushies are gone, bad energy policy ideas will have powerful constituencies, while good ideas won\xe2\x80\x99t.'b'Subsidizing ethanol benefits two well-organized groups: corn growers and ethanol producers (especially the corporate giant Archer Daniels Midland). As a result, it\xe2\x80\x99s bad policy with bipartisan support. For example, earlier this month legislation calling for a huge increase in ethanol use was introduced by five senators, of whom four, including presidential aspirants Barack Obama and Joseph Biden, were Democrats. In a recent town meeting in Iowa, Hillary Clinton managed to mention ethanol twice, according to The Politico.'b'Meanwhile, conservation doesn\xe2\x80\x99t have anything like the same natural political mojo. Where\xe2\x80\x99s the organized, powerful constituency for tougher fuel economy standards, a higher gasoline tax, or a cap-and-trade system on carbon dioxide emissions?'b'Can anything be done to promote good energy policy? Public education is a necessary first step, which is why Al Gore deserves all the praise he\xe2\x80\x99s getting. It would also help to have a president who got scientific advice from scientists, not oil company executives and novelists.'b'But there\xe2\x80\x99s still a huge gap between what obviously should be done and what seems politically possible. And I don\xe2\x80\x99t know how to close that gap.'b'President Bush doesn\xe2\x80\x99t seem to care that Congress wants a bigger role in guiding the Iraq war. Talking about his plan to send in 20,000 additional  troops, he said on \xe2\x80\x9c60 Minutes\xe2\x80\x9d that he knows Congress can vote against it, \xe2\x80\x9cbut I\xe2\x80\x99ve made my decision and we\xe2\x80\x99re going forward.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'It is hardly the first time this president has insisted that  he is \xe2\x80\x9cthe decider,\xe2\x80\x9d or even the first time he\xe2\x80\x99s used the Constitution to justify it, as Vice President Dick Cheney did when he told Fox News: \xe2\x80\x9cThe Constitution is very clear that the president is, in fact, under Article 2, the commander in chief.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'But Mr. Cheney  told only half the story. Congress has war powers, too, and with 70 percent  of Americans now opposed to President Bush\xe2\x80\x99s handling of the war, according to an ABC News/Washington Post poll, it is becoming more assertive about them. Congress is poised to pass a resolution denouncing the troop increase. Down the line, Congress may well consider mandatory caps on the number of troops in Iraq, or setting a date for withdrawal.'b'If it does, we may be headed toward a constitutional clash, with the administration trying to read powers into the Constitution \xe2\x80\x94 as it has with its \xe2\x80\x9cenemy combatant\xe2\x80\x9d doctrine and presidential \xe2\x80\x9csigning statements\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 that the Founders did not put there. The Constitution\xe2\x80\x99s drafters were intent on balancing power so no one branch could drift toward despotism. The system of checks and balances that runs through the document divides the war power between the president and Congress.'b'The Constitution\xe2\x80\x99s provision that the president is the commander in chief clearly puts him at the top of the military chain of command. Congress would be overstepping if, for example, it passed a law requiring generals in the field to report directly to the speaker of the House.'b'But the Constitution also gives Congress an array of war powers, including the power to \xe2\x80\x9cdeclare war,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9craise and support armies\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cmake rules concerning captures on land and water.\xe2\x80\x9d By \xe2\x80\x9cdeclare war,\xe2\x80\x9d the Constitution\xe2\x80\x99s framers did not mean merely firing off a starting gun. In the 18th century, war declarations were often limited in scope \xe2\x80\x94   European powers might fight a naval battle in the Americas, for example, but not  battle on their own continent. In giving Congress the power to declare war, the Constitution gives it authority to make decisions about a war\xe2\x80\x99s scope and duration.'b'The Founders, including James Madison, who is often called \xe2\x80\x9cthe father of the Constitution,\xe2\x80\x9d fully expected Congress to use these powers to rein in the commander in chief. \xe2\x80\x9cThe constitution supposes, what the History of all Governments demonstrates, that the Executive is the branch of power most interested in war, and most prone to it,\xe2\x80\x9d Madison cautioned. \xe2\x80\x9cIt has accordingly with studied care, vested the question of war in the Legislature.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'In the early days of the republic, the Supreme Court made clear that Congress could limit the president\xe2\x80\x99s war powers \xe2\x80\x94 notably in the Flying Fish case. In 1799, during the \xe2\x80\x9cQuasi War,\xe2\x80\x9d the undeclared sea war between the United States and France, Congress authorized President John Adams to clamp down on trade between the two nations by stopping ships headed to French ports. But Adams went further, ordering commanders to stop ships that were sailing to or from a French port.'b'When the Flying Fish was seized while sailing from a French port \xe2\x80\x94 something Congress had not authorized \xe2\x80\x94 the ship\xe2\x80\x99s owner sued. The Supreme Court decided in his favor, ruling that the president had no right to issue the order he did. John Marshall, the nation\xe2\x80\x99s greatest chief justice, declared that even in a time of hostilities, a president\xe2\x80\x99s decision to act militarily beyond what Congress had authorized was \xe2\x80\x9cunlawful.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'The court has repeatedly reinforced this principle. In 1952, in the steel seizure case, it ruled that President  Harry Truman could not seize steel mills to avert a strike \xe2\x80\x94 even though steel was needed for the Korean War \xe2\x80\x94 because Congress had set out a different way of handling the labor unrest. More recently, in Hamdan v. Rumsfeld, it held that President Bush must follow Congressional guidelines when he sets up military tribunals for detainees.'b'Past Congresses have enacted just the sort of restrictions the Bush administration is trying to foreclose today. During the Vietnam War, the Foreign Assistance Act of 1974 capped the number of American military personnel in South Vietnam at 4,000 within six months. The Lebanon Emergency Assistance Act of 1983 required the president to get Congress\xe2\x80\x99s approval for any substantial increase in the number or role of armed forces in Lebanon.'b'There is little question that Congress could use its power of the purse to end a war. But cutting off financing is a drastic step, and one that members of Congress are understandably reluctant to take, because it can look like a refusal to support the troops. The Constitution\xe2\x80\x99s text, Supreme Court cases and history show, however, that Congress can instead pass laws that set the terms of military engagement. Whether it would be wise for Congress to adopt such limits is debatable; whether it has the authority to do so should not be.'b'The Bush administration insists that if Congress tries to manage the Iraq war, it will leave the commander in chief with too little authority. But the greater danger is the one Madison recognized at the nation\xe2\x80\x99s founding \xe2\x80\x94 that all the power will be left with the person \xe2\x80\x9cmost interested in war, and most prone to it.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'To the Editor:'b'Re \xe2\x80\x9cThe Mystery of the Chinese Baby Shortage,\xe2\x80\x9d by Beth Nonte Russell (Op-Ed, Jan. 23):'b'When I visited Wanxian, China, in the fall of 2005, I talked to local Chinese and visited an orphanage. More than 190 DNA exonerations in 18 years show ever more alarming patterns of citizens, wrongly convicted, suffering in prison. Or the 12 people who had to fight long and hard to prove their innocence in Dallas County, Tex., alone in the past five years. New York and Texas are, in fact, the leading states in yielding these hard-fought exonerations. Block'b'Somerville, Mass., Jan. 26, 2007'b''b'The writer is a doctoral candidate in health policy at Harvard.'b''b'FOR the past two decades, New York has been an inspiration to other American cities looking to revive themselves. Yes, New York had a lot of crime, but somehow it also still had neighborhoods, and a core that had never been completely abandoned to the car. Lately, though, as far as pedestrian issues go, New York is acting more like the rest of America, and the rest of America is acting more like the once-inspiring New York.'b'As a New Yorker who has spent two years researching roads and transportation across the United States, I am saddened to see our city falling behind places like downtown Albuquerque, where one-way streets have become more pedestrian-friendly two-way streets, and car lanes are replaced by bike lanes, with bike racks everywhere.'b'Then there is Grand Rapids, Mich., which has a walkable downtown with purposely limited parking and is home to a new bus plaza that is part of a mass transit renaissance in Michigan. The state is investing in high-speed trains, and it is even talking about a mass transit system for the nation\xe2\x80\x99s auto-capital, Detroit, where a new pedestrian plaza anchors downtown. In Indianapolis, an urban walking and biking trail will soon link inner-city neighborhoods \xe2\x80\x94 something New York certainly hasn\xe2\x80\x99t tried.'b'We have lost our golden pedestrian touch in New York mostly because we still think about traffic as though it were 1950, and we needed Robert Moses to plow a few giant freeways through town to get the cars moving again. But the fact is that more roads equal more traffic.'b'London now charges drivers a fee to enter the core business area, but here such initiatives are branded as anti-car, and thus anti-personal freedom: a congestion fee, critics say, is a tax on the middle-class car commuter. But as matters now stand, the pedestrian is taxed every day: by delays and emissions, by asthma rates that are (in the Bronx) as much as four times the national average. Though we think of it as a luxury, the car taxes us, and with it we tax others.'b'And yet, here in New York, we even have the debate over bicycle traffic backwards. We focus on drivers\xe2\x80\x99 complaints about the bicycle commuter who races through red lights, rather than on the concerns of the mother biking her child around organic-food delivery trucks that idle in bike-only lanes. In December, the police say, a bicyclist was killed on the Hudson River Greenway by a drunken driver speeding along a bike lane that was completely separated from the road. Asked what was being done to improve safety in light of the biker\xe2\x80\x99s death, Mayor Michael Bloomberg suggested that bikers \xe2\x80\x9cpay attention.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'\xe2\x80\x9cEven if they\xe2\x80\x99re in the right, they are the lightweights,\xe2\x80\x9d he told a reporter.'b'Contrast this response with that of Mayor Richard Daley of Chicago after a 4-year-old pedestrian was killed in a hit and run. Mayor Daley immediately set up a pedestrian awareness program, suggested that police sting operations arrest speeding drivers and proposed to add 500 miles of bike lanes, so that there would be one within a half-mile of every resident.'b'One reason New York is losing its New York edge may be that the city\xe2\x80\x99s revival is partly based on a strange reversal: the city is the new suburb. Families have returned to the New York that was abandoned years ago for lawns and better public schools. They\xe2\x80\x99ve brought with them a love of cars. A new study by Bruce Schaller, a local transportation consultant, shows that half the drivers in Manhattan are from the city \xe2\x80\x94 and that more city residents than suburbanites drive to work every day.'b'New Yorkers always find good reasons to drive. Public transportation is dirty, time-consuming, a hassle, unsafe. Walking takes too long. The children will be late for school. But choosing the car is no longer safe \xe2\x80\x94 for your children who already don\xe2\x80\x99t get enough exercise, for anyone\xe2\x80\x99s lungs or for the future of New York as a livable place. There are even such things as secondhand driving effects: studies show that people who live on high-traffic streets tend to stay inside.'b'The simple and elegant cure for the loss of New York\xe2\x80\x99s inner pedestrian is to open up car-clogged streets and public spaces. Another of Mr. Schaller\xe2\x80\x99s surveys, sponsored by the citizens\xe2\x80\x99 group Transportation Alternatives, showed that 89 percent of people questioned on Prince Street in SoHo got there by subway, bus, foot or bicycle, and that the majority would gladly give up parking for more pedestrian space.'b'With a million more New Yorkers scheduled to arrive by 2030, true sustainability requires the city \xe2\x80\x94 or at least its residents \xe2\x80\x94 to make a bold move. In Williamsburg, Brooklyn, the city\xe2\x80\x99s Department of Transportation has replaced parking spaces near a subway station with rows of bike racks.'b'But these are tiny steps. Mohamed ElBaradei, head of the International Atomic Energy Agency, has warned of 30 \xe2\x80\x9cvirtual new weapons states\xe2\x80\x9d on the horizon. Obviously, the more countries that possess the bomb, the higher the risk of a nuclear accident, the theft of a weapon, sales of technology and hardware, and a serious miscalculation leading to nuclear war.'b'So where should Mr. Ban start? With North Korea having declared after its test last October that it now possesses a nuclear deterrent, the understandable temptation will be to focus on Iran. This would be a mistake. North Korea is still some way off from having a reliable nuclear weapon, and to accept its having this capacity as a fait accompli would not only play into its game plan but also convince Iran and other countries that the international community lacks the will to prevent them from developing the bomb. A new approach is required.'b'The logical place to look is to examine the lessons of \xe2\x80\x9cnuclear reversal\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 that is, what has made states in the past give up the nuclear option. At first glance, the historical record doesn\xe2\x80\x99t look encouraging: South Africa is the only country that has developed nuclear weapons and then destroyed them. Yet other nations have abandoned advanced research programs \xe2\x80\x94 including Australia, Argentina, Brazil, South Korea, Sweden and Taiwan \xe2\x80\x94 or, like Belarus, Kazakhstan and Ukraine, given up the nuclear arsenals they inherited from the Soviet Union. One big reason for these countries\xe2\x80\x99 decisions, not surprisingly, was the efforts of major powers to reassure them about their long-term security, so that nuclear weapons offered no appreciable benefit.'b'How would this approach be applied to North Korea? The answer is not unilateral assurances from the United States. American officials have vowed many times that they harbor no hostile intent; repeating that mantra will not make it any more credible to Pyongyang. Similar guarantees from all five of the permanent members of the Security Council, however, could be more persuasive. Enter Mr. Ban.'b'The diplomatic vehicle for such security assurances would be a United Nations-sponsored initiative to formally end the Korean War and dismantle the present armistice arrangements. As part of a peace treaty, the principal signatories \xe2\x80\x94 the United States, China and the two Koreas \xe2\x80\x94 would commit themselves to establishing normal diplomatic relations, recognizing the territorial integrity of both Koreas and, most important, ensuring a nuclear-free peninsula.'b'To sweeten the deal, the Security Council\xe2\x80\x99s permanent five would extend security guarantees, similar to those given Ukraine, to both Koreas. These would remain in effect as long as each side fulfilled its nonproliferation commitment. If one or the other reneged, all bets would be off.'b'Complementary agreements involving conventional arms control, economic assistance, access to international financial institutions and humanitarian aid could also be discussed, but not as prerequisites for replacing the Korean armistice with a permanent peace settlement.'b'The United States has already signaled its willingness to sign a peace treaty \xe2\x80\x94 but only after North Korea verifiably dismantled its nuclear weapons. Hale'b'\nNew York, Jan. 25, 2007'b''b'Washington'b'PRESIDENT BUSH seems not to have noticed, but what stands between hostile sectarian forces and the resumption of all-out civil war in Lebanon is the Arab League, whose diplomacy 17 years ago put an end to a conflict in which tens of thousands of Lebanese died. At that time, the Arab League\xe2\x80\x99s goal was to prevent the chaos in Lebanon from spreading to the wider Arab world. That remains the league\xe2\x80\x99s goal today, both in Lebanon and in Iraq. But it also has another concern: with Tehran\xe2\x80\x99s regional power rising, the Arab League has a deep interest in keeping both countries in the Arab sphere, free of Iranian domination.'b'The United States finds itself increasingly unable to stem the violence in Iraq, and it seems unlikely that a surge of troops will strengthen American influence. Mr. Bush may still consider himself a liberator, but among Iraqis there is a widespread feeling that his invasion was just the latest crime of Western imperialism.'b'Curiously, the Iraq Study Group, in acknowledging Iraqi distrust of the United States, suggested a greater diplomatic role for Syria and Iran, the very countries that have an interest in Iraq\xe2\x80\x99s instability. The United States cannot.'b'The Arab League\xe2\x80\x99s Baghdad offices are recognized by the Shiite government of Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki. President Jalal Talabani, a Kurd, has strongly supported Iraq\xe2\x80\x99s involvement with the Arab League. Amr Moussa, the Arab League\xe2\x80\x99s secretary general, has had an open door not just to Iraqi officials but also to Moktada al-Sadr, the radical Shiite leader, and to Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani, the country\xe2\x80\x99s most powerful cleric, who has never received an American official. The Iraqi foreign minister, a Kurd, has participated regularly in Arab League meetings.'b'To be sure, the Arab League cannot offer miracles. The situation in Iraq has deteriorated much too far for that. But with an invitation from the American president, it could immediately get to work at mediating the conflict.'b'If the objective is political stability and national reconciliation in Iraq, neither President Bush nor the Democratic Congress has a more promising option.'b'Canada set an important example of decency when it offered a formal apology and compensation worth millions of dollars to a Syrian-born Canadian citizen who was a victim of President Bush\xe2\x80\x99s use of open-ended detention, summary deportation and even torture in the name of fighting terrorism.'b'Last week\xe2\x80\x99s announcement by Prime Minister Stephen Harper came  more than four  years after the nightmare began for the Canadian, Maher Arar, a 36-year-old software engineer. On his way back from a family vacation, he was detained by U.S. officials at Kennedy Airport on the basis of unsubstantiated information from the Canadian police. After being held in solitary confinement in a Brooklyn detention center and interrogated without proper access to legal counsel, he was sent to Syria, where he was imprisoned for nearly a year and tortured.'b'It was all part of a legally and morally unsupportable practice known as extraordinary rendition, the deportation of terrorism suspects to countries where the regimes are known to use torture and to disdain basic human rights protections.'b'Four months ago, a Canadian government panel concluded that Mr. Arar had never had a terrorism connection, and that Americans had misled Canada about their plans for him. The Bush administration stonewalled the inquiry. It has responded to a new Canadian request to remove Mr. Arar from a United States security watch list by rudely telling Canada, its democratic northern neighbor and strategic ally, to mind its own business.'b'Not only has the Bush administration refused to apologize to Mr. Arar, but Justice Department lawyers are also brandishing a dubious claim of state secrets and fighting a lawsuit brought by Mr. Arar in this country. Bush administration officials insist that they have \xe2\x80\x9cnew intelligence\xe2\x80\x9d that justifies keeping Mr. Arar on the watch list. That intelligence has not been disclosed, but Canadian officials who have reviewed the information are unpersuaded.'b'Questioned about the Arar case at a recent Senate Judiciary Committee hearing, Attorney General Alberto Gonzales provided no specifics that would explain Mr. Arar\xe2\x80\x99s continued presence on the watch list, or why he had been deported to Syria in the first place. The committee\xe2\x80\x99s chairman, Senator Patrick Leahy, Democrat of Vermont, is right to demand that the administration face up to its bad behavior in this case and renounce its renditions policy.'b'This is not just about making amends with Canada, or doing the right thing by someone who   appears to be an innocent man. It is a matter of trying to restore this country\xe2\x80\x99s reputation as a defender and protector of human rights.'b'To the Editor:'b''b'\xe2\x80\x9cTo Food Pantry, Even Fruitcake Is a Help\xe2\x80\x9d'b' (news article, Jan. 26) negates the important role of the emergency food system.'b'Fruitcake, cookies and exotic donations are not what we\xe2\x80\x99re about. The Food Bank for New York City provides nutritional training and a wide range of nutritious food to soup kitchens and food pantries \xe2\x80\x94 most of which is financed by government programs.'b'The current shortage of food in the system is driven largely by prolonged cuts in government financing, which have led to a dramatic drop in the amount of food provided by government-financed programs in the past five years.'b'To maintain an adequate supply of nutritious emergency food, an increase in government financing to match existing need and increased private donations of fresh food are vital. But nutritious emergency food is just the first step.'b'To reach our ultimate goal to end hunger, the Food Bank and its network of soup kitchens and food pantries promote the enrollment of eligible New Yorkers for food stamps and other benefits, as well as the development of permanent access to affordable, nutritious food in low-income neighborhoods.'b'\xc3\x81ine Duggan'b'\nNew York, Jan. 26, 2007'b''b'The writer is vice president of government relations, policy and research at the Food Bank for New York City. 'b''b''b''b'DAVOS, Switzerland'b'The World Economic Forum here in Davos is the kind of place where if you let yourself get distracted while walking by a European prime minister on your left, you could end up tripping over a famous gazillionaire \xe2\x80\x94 and then spilling your coffee onto the king on your right. But perhaps the most remarkable people to attend aren\xe2\x80\x99t the world leaders or other bigwigs.'b'Rather, they are the social entrepreneurs. Davos, which has always been uncanny in peeking just ahead of the curve to reflect the zeitgeist of the moment, swarmed with them.'b'So what\xe2\x80\x99s a social entrepreneur? Let me give a few examples among those at the forum in Davos.'b'\xe2\x80\xa2 In Africa, where children die of diarrhea from bad sanitation, Isaac Durojaiye runs a franchise system for public toilets. He supplies mobile toilets to slum areas, where unemployed young people charge a small fee for their use. The operators keep 60 percent of the income and pass the rest back to Mr. Durojaiye\xe2\x80\x99s company, Dignified Mobile Toilets, which uses the money to buy new toilets.'b'\xe2\x80\xa2 Nic Frances runs a group that aims to cut carbon emissions in 70 percent of Australian households over 10 years. His group, Easy Being Green, gives out low-energy light bulbs and low-flow shower heads \xe2\x80\x94 after the household signs over the rights to the carbon emissions the equipment will save. The group then sells those carbon credits to industry to finance its activities, and it is now aiming to expand globally.'b'\xe2\x80\xa2 In the U.S., Gillian Caldwell and her group, Witness, train people around the world to use video cameras to document human rights abuses. The resulting videos have drawn public attention to issues like child soldiers and the treatment of the mentally ill. Now Ms. Caldwell aims to create a sort of YouTube for human rights video clips.'b'Social entrepreneurs like Ms. Caldwell resemble traditional do-gooders in their yearning to make the world a better place, but sound like chief executives when they talk about metrics to assess cost-effectiveness. Many also generate income to finance expansion.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99re totally self-sustaining,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mirai Chatterjee, a dynamo who is coordinator of the Self-Employed Women\xe2\x80\x99s Association in India. \xe2\x80\x9cFrom Day 1 our idea was to run a strong economic organization.\xe2\x80\x9d Ms. Chatterjee\xe2\x80\x99s organization now has nearly 1 million members, owns a bank, runs 100 day care centers, trains midwives and provides health insurance for 200,000 women. It is empowering women and fighting poverty across a growing swath of rural India, and its down-to-earth approach is characteristic of social entrepreneurs.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cPolitics is failing to solve all the big issues,\xe2\x80\x9d said Jim Wallis, who wrote \xe2\x80\x9cGod\xe2\x80\x99s Politics\xe2\x80\x9d and runs Sojourners, which pushes social justice issues. \xe2\x80\x9cSo when that happens, social movements rise up.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Muhammad Yunus, who won the Nobel Peace Prize last year, demonstrated with Grameen Bank the power of microfinancing. His bank has helped raise incomes, secure property rights for women, lower population growth and raise education standards across Bangladesh \xe2\x80\x94 and now the success is rippling around the globe.'b'One of those inspired by Mr. Yunus, for example, was Roshaneh Zafar, a young Pakistani economist. She quit her job and started Kashf, a microfinance institution that now gives hundreds of thousands of Pakistani women a route out of poverty.'b'Ms. Zafar also received help from Ashoka, a hugely influential organization for social entrepreneurs started by an American, Bill Drayton (who describes social entrepreneurs as \xe2\x80\x9cthe most important historical force at work today\xe2\x80\x9d). Ashoka is one of a growing number of donor groups that offer the equivalent of venture capital for social entrepreneurs.'b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe key with social entrepreneurs is their pragmatic approach,\xe2\x80\x9d said Pamela Hartigan of the Schwab Foundation for Social Entrepreneurship, which is affiliated with the World Economic Forum. \xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99re not out there with protest banners; they\xe2\x80\x99re actually developing concrete solutions.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'When I travel around the world, I\xe2\x80\x99m blown away by how these people are transforming lives. A growing number of the best and brightest university graduates in the U.S. and abroad are moving into this area (many clutching the book \xe2\x80\x9cHow to Change the World,\xe2\x80\x9d a bible in the field).'b'It\xe2\x80\x99s one of the most hopeful and helpful trends around. These folks aren\xe2\x80\x99t famous, and they didn\xe2\x80\x99t fly to Davos in first-class cabins or private jets, but they are showing that what it really takes to change the world isn\xe2\x80\x99t so much wealth or power as creativity, determination and passion.'b'Twenty years ago, the Florida Legislature cravenly decided to allow \xe2\x80\x9claw abiding\xe2\x80\x9d citizens to carry concealed weapons merely by declaring their preference for self-defense. Then last July, at the prodding of the gun lobby, the current crop of state lawmakers proved they could be even more corrupt and cowardly than their predecessors by deciding to make the list of gun-toting Floridians a secret.'b'Fortunately, a local newspaper has given residents of the state a look at their representatives\xe2\x80\x99 gruesome handiwork.'b'When the law was first enacted, there were fewer than 25,000 licensed gun holders. Since then, the state roll has boomed to 410,000 and counting. As the veil descends on this dangerously macho part of the public record, enterprising articles in The South Florida Sun-Sentinel are laying bare the fact that more than 1,400 people easily got gun licenses despite pleading guilty or no contest to felonies that included manslaughter, burglary and child molestation. In Broward County alone, gun licenses grew in 20 years to more than 35,000 from 25.'b'Sampling records just before the law took effect, the newspaper uncovered hundreds of tales of mayhem, official indifference and glaring loopholes in criminal justice protection. One man got a license after pleading no contest to manslaughter in fatally shooting his girlfriend in the head while she cooked him breakfast. Another applicant was licensed despite guilty pleas to   an assault charge,   for holding a handgun against his roommate\xe2\x80\x99s head  in an argument, and to a later grand theft charge.'b'Those permitted to pack concealed weapons include 216 people with outstanding criminal warrants, 128 under domestic violence injunctions and 6 registered sex offenders.'b'The gun lobby, predictably enough, is blaming \xe2\x80\x9cbleeding-heart, criminal-coddling judges and prosecutors\xe2\x80\x9d for this grim state of affairs. The truth is that the National Rifle Association has succeeded too well in herding legislators to do its dangerous bidding. Lawmakers in 38 states have approved bills allowing citizens to carry concealed weapons.'b'As in some of those states, Florida\xe2\x80\x99s legislators take the position that it\xe2\x80\x99s no fun to have a gun if you can\xe2\x80\x99t use it. So they loosened the laws on self-defense to allow a civilian to stand and use deadly force \xe2\x80\x9cif he or she reasonably believes it is necessary.\xe2\x80\x9d If lawmakers had any sense of shame, they would undo these lethal threats to their constituents.'b'Why should we feel so much grief at the loss of one horse? After all, this is a world in which horses are sacrificed again and again for the sport of humans. Barbaro was euthanized yesterday, eight months after he shattered his right hind leg at the start of the Preakness Stakes. After an injury like that, most racehorses would have been put down minutes later. But every race is a complex equation \xe2\x80\x94 a balance of economics, athleticism, equine grace and conscience. Conscience often comes in last, but not in this case. Barbaro\xe2\x80\x99s owners gave that horse exactly what he had given them, which is everything. It was the very least they could do, and yet it seemed truly exceptional in a sport that is   barbarous as often as it is beautiful.'b'Barbaro was exceptional because he won the Kentucky Derby and looked as if he might have a chance at the Triple Crown. But nearly everyone who met him also talked of the life he displayed, a vivid presence that was so much more visible to us because it happened to belong to a winner.'b'Humans are not especially good at noticing horses, but Barbaro was easy to notice. And if his life caused us to pay attention to the possibilities of all horses, his death should cause us to pay attention to the tragedy inherent in the end of so many horses. Barbaro\xe2\x80\x99s death was tragic not because it was measured against the races he might have won or even against the effort to save his life. It was tragic because of what every horse is.'b'You would have to look a long, long time to find a dishonest or cruel horse. And the odds are that if you did find one, it was made cruel or dishonest by the company it kept with humans. It is no exaggeration to say that nearly every horse \xe2\x80\x94 Barbaro included \xe2\x80\x94 is pure of heart. Some are faster, some slower. Some wind up in the winner\xe2\x80\x99s circle. But they should all evoke in us the generosity of conscience \xe2\x80\x94 a human quality, after all \xe2\x80\x94 that was expended in the effort to save this one horse.'b'To the Editor:'b'Re 'b'\xe2\x80\x9cLimits on Prison Suits Are Eased\xe2\x80\x9d'b' (news article, Jan. 23):'b'The Supreme Court did well to reject the procedural obstacles to inmate litigation that federal courts have added to those already placed by the Prison Litigation Reform Act of 1995.'b'But this is mere tinkering at the edges.'b'After a decade of experience, it is abundantly clear that Congress should drastically overhaul it.'b'Departments of correction have used the Prison Litigation Reform Act to deny far too many prisoners a fair chance of getting a judicial remedy when they become victims of appalling medical care, staff violence and sexual harassment, among other serious prison abuses.'b'Jamie Fellner'b'\nDirector, U.S. Program'b'\nHuman Rights Watch'b'\nNew York, Jan. 23, 2007'b''b''b''b'In 1975, after  the oil embargo, Congress approved the most successful energy-saving measure this country has ever seen: the Corporate Average Fuel Economy system, known as CAFE, which set minimum mileage standards for cars. Within 10 years, automobile efficiency had virtually doubled, to 27.5 miles per gallon in 1985 from just over 14 miles per gallon in 1976.'b'The mileage standards are still 27.5 m.p.g. Except for minor tweaks, Congress has refused to raise fuel efficiency requirements or close a gaping loophole that lets S.U.V.\xe2\x80\x99s and pickups be measured by a more lenient standard.'b'Americans who heard President Bush\xe2\x80\x99s State of the Union address, including his pledge to reduce America\xe2\x80\x99s gasoline consumption, can be forgiven for thinking he was finally ready to change that. Rather than requiring companies to meet an average fuel-efficiency standard, balancing gas savers against gas guzzlers, he would assign targets model by model, based on factors like size and weight.'b'As for what those new targets might be, Mr. Bush would leave it to his secretary of transportation to decide. They were right.  Norman Charles'b'New York, Jan. 30, 2007'b'On Election Day last fall in Maryland, fliers were handed out in black neighborhoods with the heading \xe2\x80\x9cDemocratic Sample Ballot\xe2\x80\x9d and photos of black Democratic leaders \xe2\x80\x94 and boxes checked off beside the names of the Republican candidates for senator and governor. They were a blatant attempt to fool black voters into thinking the Republican candidates were endorsed by black Democrats. In Orange County, Calif., 14,000 Latino voters got letters in Spanish saying it was a crime for immigrants to vote in a federal election. It didn\xe2\x80\x99t say that immigrants who are citizens have the right to vote.'b'Dirty tricks like these turn up every election season, in large part because they are so rarely punished. But two Democratic senators, Barack Obama of Illinois and Charles Schumer of New York, are introducing a bill today that would make deceiving or intimidating voters a federal crime with substantial penalties.'b'The bill aims at some of the most commonly used deceptive political tactics. It makes it a crime to knowingly tell voters the wrong day for an election. There have been numerous reports of organized efforts to use telephones, leaflets or posters to tell voters, especially in minority areas, not to vote on Election Day because voting has been postponed.'b'The bill would also criminalize making false claims to voters about who has endorsed a candidate, or wrongly telling people \xe2\x80\x94 like immigrants who are registered voters in Orange County \xe2\x80\x94 that they cannot vote.'b'Along with defining these crimes and providing penalties of up to five years\xe2\x80\x99 imprisonment, the bill would require the Justice Department to counteract deceptive election information that has been put out, and to report to Congress after each election on what deceptive practices occurred and what the Justice Department did about them.'b'The bill would also allow individuals to go to court to stop deceptive practices while they are happening. That is important, given how uninterested the current Justice Department has proved to be in cracking down on election-season dirty tricks.'b'The bill is careful to avoid infringing on First Amendment rights, and that is the right course. But in steering clear of regulating speech, it is not clear how effective the measure would be in addressing one of the worst dirty tricks of last fall\xe2\x80\x99s election: a particular kind of deceptive \xe2\x80\x9crobocall\xe2\x80\x9d that was used against Democratic Congressional candidates. These calls, paid for by the Republicans, sounded as if they had come from the Democrat; when a recipient hung up, the call was repeated over and over. The intent was clearly to annoy the recipients so they would not vote for the Democrat.'b'While there are already laws that can be used against this sort of deceptive telephone harassment, a more specific bill aimed directly at these calls is needed. But the bill being introduced today is an important step toward making elections more honest and fair. There is no reason it should not be passed by Congress unanimously.'b'Here\xe2\x80\x99s a little foreign policy test. Country A is Iran. Country B is Saudi Arabia.'b'Don\xe2\x80\x99t worry. I know that Iran has also engaged in terrorism against the U.S. and that the Saudis have supported America at key times in some areas. The point I\xe2\x80\x99m trying to make, though, is that the hostility between Iran and the U.S. since the overthrow of the shah in 1979 is not organic. By dint of culture, history and geography, we actually have a lot of interests in common with Iran\xe2\x80\x99s people. And I am not the only one to notice that.'b'Because the U.S. has destroyed Iran\xe2\x80\x99s two biggest enemies \xe2\x80\x94 the Taliban and Saddam \xe2\x80\x94 \xe2\x80\x9cthere is now a debate in Iran as to whether we should continue to act so harshly against the Americans,\xe2\x80\x9d Mohammad Hossein Adeli, Iran\xe2\x80\x99s former ambassador to London, told me at Davos. \xe2\x80\x9cThere is now more readiness for dialogue with the United States.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'More important, when people say, \xe2\x80\x9cThe most important thing America could do today to stabilize the Middle East is solve the Israel-Palestine conflict,\xe2\x80\x9d they are wrong. It\xe2\x80\x99s second. The most important thing would be to resolve the Iran-U.S. conflict.'b'That would change the whole Middle East and open up the way to solving the Israel-Palestine conflict, because Iran is the key backer of Hamas, Islamic Jihad, Hezbollah and Syria. Iran\xe2\x80\x99s active help could also be critical for stabilizing Iraq.'b'This is why I oppose war with Iran. I favor negotiations. Isolating Iran like Castro\xe2\x80\x99s Cuba has produced only the same result as in Cuba: strengthening Iran\xe2\x80\x99s Castros. But for talks with Iran to bear fruit, we have to negotiate with Iran 'b'with leverage'b'.'b'How do we get leverage? Had the president been an ordinary  citizen \xe2\x80\x94 someone charged with bank robbery or income tax evasion \xe2\x80\x94 the wheels of justice would have immediately begun to turn. The F.B.I. would have conducted  an investigation, a United States attorney\xe2\x80\x99s office would have impaneled a grand jury and charges would have been brought.'b'But under the Bush Justice Department, no F.B.I. agents were ever dispatched to padlock White House files or knock on doors and no federal prosecutors ever opened a case.'b'The ruling was the result of a suit, in which I am one of the plaintiffs, brought against the National Security Agency by the American Civil Liberties Union. It was a response to revelations by this newspaper  in December 2005 that the agency had been monitoring the phone calls and e-mail  messages of Americans for more than four years without first obtaining warrants from the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court, as required by the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act.'b'In the past, even presidents were not above the law. When the F.B.I. turned up evidence during Watergate that Richard Nixon had obstructed justice by trying to cover up his involvement, a special prosecutor was named and a House committee recommended that the president be impeached.'b'And when an independent counsel found evidence that President Bill Clinton had committed perjury in the Monica Lewinsky case, the  impeachment machinery again cranked into gear, with the spectacle of a Senate trial (which ended in acquittal).'b'Laws are broken, the federal government investigates, and the individuals involved \xe2\x80\x94 even if they\xe2\x80\x99re presidents \xe2\x80\x94 are tried and, if found guilty, punished. That is the way it is supposed to work under our system of government. But not this time.'b'Last  Aug. 17,   Judge Anna Diggs Taylor of the United States District Court in Detroit issued her ruling in the A.C.L.U. case. The president, she wrote, had \xe2\x80\x9cundisputedly violated\xe2\x80\x9d not only the First and Fourth Amendments of the Constitution, but also statutory law, the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act. Enacted by a bipartisan Congress in 1978, the FISA statute was a response to revelations that the National Security Agency had conducted warrantless eavesdropping on Americans. To deter future administrations from similar actions, the law  made  a violation a felony punishable by a $10,000 fine and five years in prison.'b'Yet despite this ruling, the Bush Justice Department never opened  an F.B.I. investigation, no special prosecutor was named,  and there was no talk of impeachment in the Republican-controlled Congress.'b'Justice Department lawyers argued last June that warrants were not required for what they called the administration\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cterrorist  surveillance program\xe2\x80\x9d  because of the president\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cinherent powers\xe2\x80\x9d to order eavesdropping and because of the Congressional authorization to use military force against those responsible for 9/11. But Judge Taylor rejected both arguments, ruling that even presidents must obey  statutory law and the Constitution.'b'On Jan.  17,  Attorney General Alberto Gonzales unexpectedly declared that President Bush had ended the program, deciding to again seek warrants in all cases. Exactly what kind of warrants \xe2\x80\x94 individual, as is required by the law, or broad-based, which would probably still be illegal \xe2\x80\x94 is as yet unknown.'b'The action may have been designed to forestall a potentially adverse ruling by the federal appeals court in Cincinnati, which had scheduled oral arguments on the case for today. At that hearing, the administration is now expected to argue that the case is moot and should be thrown out \xe2\x80\x94 while reserving the right to restart the program at any time.'b'But that\xe2\x80\x99s a bit like a bank robber coming into court and arguing that, although he has been sticking up banks for the past half-decade, he has agreed to a temporary halt and therefore he shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be prosecuted. Independent of the A.C.L.U.  case, a criminal investigation by the F.B.I. and a special prosecutor should begin immediately. The question that must finally be answered is whether the president is guilty of committing a felony by continuously reauthorizing the warrantless eavesdropping program for the past five years. And if so, what action must be taken?'b'The issue is not original. Among the charges approved by the House Judiciary Committee  when it recommended  its articles  of impeachment against President Nixon was \xe2\x80\x9cillegal wiretaps.\xe2\x80\x9d President Nixon, the bill charged, \xe2\x80\x9ccaused wiretaps to be placed on the telephones of 17 persons without having obtained a court order authorizing the tap, as required by federal law; in violation of Sections 241, 371 and 2510-11 of the Criminal Code.\xe2\x80\x9d'b'Under his program, President Bush could probably be charged with wiretapping not 17 but thousands of  people  without having obtained a court order authorizing the taps  as required by federal law, in violation of FISA.'b'It is not only the federal court but also many in Congress  who believe that a violation of law has taken place. And yet it sells well because it is the only kind of poem available for more than half the year, and people insist on reading poetry, even out of season. That is the winter tomato. In redness and roundness it says \xe2\x80\x9ctomato,\xe2\x80\x9d in every way except the one that matters: flavor.'b'Earlier this month, the federal Agriculture Department put an exception into its rules to let a tomato called the UglyRipe be shipped out of state. Those rules say a tomato must be at least 2 9/32 inches and no more than 2 25/32 inches in diameter. The UglyRipe doesn\xe2\x80\x99t meet those specs \xe2\x80\x94 it\xe2\x80\x99s ribbed at the top and not uniform in shape. It is also reputed to taste very much like a tomato.'b'Perhaps the real virtue of the UglyRipe\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cugliness,\xe2\x80\x9d which is nothing compared with the deformed beauty of true heirloom tomatoes, is that it helps us see how strange the uniformity of regular winter tomatoes really is. For a backyard grower, taste is everything. But in commercial production, taste is an abstraction. It is what\xe2\x80\x99s left after all the other criteria for a good commercial tomato have been met: disease resistance, regular shape, consistent ripening, the ability to withstand picking and packing and shipping, a long shelf life. Taste is too subjective, according to the Florida Tomato Committee, to judge tomatoes by.'b'The UglyRipe may be a better tomato. After all, its growers have selected for better taste, not perfect shape. But one thing that would certainly make the UglyRipe a better tomato is a different way of growing it. Santa Sweets produces organic UglyRipes, but they are few and hard to find. It now grows its conventional tomatoes without using agricultural chemicals that carry reproductive risks \xe2\x80\x94 but it still uses methyl bromide, a powerful, ozone-depleting pesticide, to fumigate the soil in which conventional UglyRipes grow.'b'Under the terms of the Montreal Protocol, the use of methyl bromide was supposed to be phased out completely by January 2005. We used to consider it a luxury to eat fruits and vegetables out of season. But what we eat out of season has been machined to withstand the rigors of the supply chain and produced in ways that only our ignorance can sustain. The truth is that there is no luxury \xe2\x80\x94 nor critical use \xe2\x80\x94 in it. Even an ugly, better-tasting winter tomato isn\xe2\x80\x99t worth the price. These allies \xe2\x80\x94 and their families \xe2\x80\x94 have become a haunted and hunted group, branded as traitors and targeted for kidnapping and assassination by insurgents and militias.'b'By any measure, the Bush administration is failing them. The current price tag for the war is $8 billion a month, yet the State Department plans to spend only $20 million in the coming fiscal year to help shelter Iraqi refugees overseas and to resettle them here. A special visa program to resettle Iraqi and Afghan military translators has been capped at 50 people a year and has a six-year waiting list.'b'Of all the Vietnam-era mistakes the country has been repeating lately, indifference to refugees is especially unforgivable. The administration can start addressing the problem by devoting a far greater number of refugee slots \xe2\x80\x94 currently 70,000 a year \xe2\x80\x94 to people from Iraq and Afghanistan. It can streamline entry procedures, which should be a manageable task for those who have already been vetted to work with the United States military.'b'It should move quickly to organize a conference with Iraq\xe2\x80\x99s neighbors to discuss ways to cope better with the human suffering and the potentially destabilizing effects of the rising human tide. And it should answer an urgent appeal for funds by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, which is seeking $60 million over the next 12 months to shelter and protect displaced Iraqis.'b'Does it really need to be said yet again that in these perilous times the way to win trustworthy allies is to be one?'b'Late last year, we tried a bit of an experiment called "Your Turn to Tell the Story." We\'re back to try it again based on our recent trip to Cambodia.'b"Stories can be told in countless ways and understood in countless forms. Here's an invitation to try your hand at a little interactive journalism."b'Below are a series of links to columns, videos, and photographs from Cambodia where the scourge of modern-day slavery ensnares thousands of women. Also, there are links to reports from NGOs, background information and news from other sources that we found to be helpful during our reporting.'b"Take a look at the material and, if you're interested, we'd like to see how you would've told the story. Use some of the quotes, the stories, the facts and weave together your own column, essay, article -- or some other kind of quilt. We can imagine someone writing a poem, a song, making up a dance, creating a video or audio slide show. Don't let convention get in the way of your storytelling. And don't feel as if it needs to be long; hey, a haiku is sometimes more effective than an epic."b"The image above, a multimedia panorama, is the handiwork of nytimes.com's "b'Gabriel Dance'b". It's a great example of re-imagining the original work. In fact, so is the CNN report from Anderson Cooper's program."b"As was said last time, we're eager to see how you'd approach things \xe2\x80\x93 what you'd do differently.
